With the growing complexity of the electric power grid, PMU placement plays an important role in ensuring the efficiency and reliability of the grid. This paper investigates the impact of system state dynamics on PMU placement in the electric power grid. It analyzes the influence of different system states on the accuracy of measurements and evaluates the effectiveness of PMU placement strategies under different scenarios. Simulation results show that the proposed PMU placement strategy can effectively minimize the impact of system state dynamics on measurements and enhance the overall system performance. This study can provide insights for power system operators and planners in making optimal decisions in PMU placement for power system monitoring and control.
column3: Impact of system state dynamics on PMU placement in the electric power  grid

column1: This paper investigates the relationship between pole placement theory and invariant subspaces. The main question of interest is whether invariant subspaces can be used to design stable closed-loop systems. We present a detailed analysis of how pole placement theory can be used to compute the desired poles for a given system, and we explore the role of invariant subspaces in this process. Our findings indicate that, under certain conditions, invariant subspaces can indeed be an effective tool for designing stable closed-loop systems. Specifically, we show that the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a system's transfer function can be used to construct an invariant subspace that is robust to disturbances and noise. Our results have important implications for control theory and have the potential to improve the stability and performance of many practical control systems.
column3: On Pole Placement and Invariant Subspaces

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for the sparse identification of posynomial models, which are commonly used in engineering and optimization applications. The proposed method leverages the sparsity-inducing properties of L1-regularization to efficiently and accurately identify the relevant posynomial terms from the available data. By incorporating domain knowledge and a priori information on the correct sign of the coefficients, the proposed method is able to identify the correct model structure even in the presence of noisy and incomplete data. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in various real-world applications, highlighting its potential for improving the accuracy and efficiency of posynomial modeling in engineering and optimization problems.
column3: Sparse Identification of Posynomial Models

column1: This paper explores the issue of resilient control under denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. Such attacks can significantly disrupt the control of complex systems and lead to catastrophic consequences. The paper proposes a new approach to resilient control that exploits the internal dynamics of the system, rather than solely relying on external defenses against DoS attacks. The proposed approach uses a combination of advanced control algorithms, distributed control, and machine learning techniques to achieve resilient control under DoS attacks. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through simulation results on a nonlinear system. The paper also discusses practical considerations for implementing the proposed approach in real-world systems, highlighting the potential benefits of this approach for enhancing the resilience of control systems against DoS attacks.
column3: Resilient Control under Denial-of-Service

column1: This paper presents a modeling and simulation framework for Electric Vehicle (EV) charging in a residential distribution power grid. The study aims to investigate the impact of EV charging on the distribution grid, particularly in terms of energy demand, grid stability, and voltage fluctuation. The proposed framework considers various scenarios of EV charging patterns, providing insights into the future demand for power infrastructure. The simulation results demonstrate the significance of integrating renewable energy sources with EV charging to reduce the dependency on traditional energy sources, enhance grid reliability, and minimize carbon emissions. This study can help in designing and developing an efficient and sustainable power grid for meeting the growing demand for EV charging in residential areas.
column3: Modeling and Simulation of the EV Charging in a Residential Distribution  Power Grid

column1: This paper describes the design of a smart electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure that is capable of fast response times. The proposed infrastructure incorporates advanced technologies such as real-time data processing, wireless communication, and cloud-based analytics to optimize EV charging efficiency and reduce charging times. The paper also discusses the challenges associated with designing such an infrastructure, including the need for robust power management systems and the integration of various EV models and charging protocols. The feasibility and benefits of the proposed infrastructure are evaluated through simulation results, and the potential for scalability and future improvements are discussed. The study concludes that a fast response smart EV charging infrastructure has the potential to significantly enhance the adoption and use of EVs.
column3: Design of Fast Response Smart Electric Vehicle Charging Infrastructure

column1: This paper presents a direct derivation of a well-known formula for the derivative of rotation matrix using matrix calculus. The formula, which is commonly used in robotics and computer vision, is crucial for determining the instantaneous angular velocity of a rotating object. The proposed approach provides a more intuitive understanding of the formula by directly computing the derivative of the rotation matrix. The resulting expression is shown to be equivalent to the traditional approach and can be easily applied to various problems involving rotation matrices.
column3: Derivative of Rotation Matrix Direct Matrix Derivation of Well Known  Formula

column1: This paper explores the design and implementation of a flywheel-based regenerative braking system for recovering energy lost during braking in typical vehicles. The proposed system utilizes a mechanical flywheel to store kinetic energy that is generated during braking and releases it to assist in the acceleration of the vehicle. The paper presents a detailed analysis of the system's operation, including mathematical models and simulations. The results demonstrate the system's effectiveness in recovering a significant amount of energy during braking, which can be used to improve fuel efficiency and reduce emissions. Overall, the proposed flywheel-based regenerative braking system provides a promising solution for sustainable energy recovery in transportation.
column3: On a Flywheel-Based Regenerative Braking System for Regenerative Energy  Recovery

column1: The prevalence of electric vehicles has significantly increased in recent years due to environmental concerns of fossil fuel usage. However, the sustainability of electric vehicles is widely debated as they are dependent on the production and disposal of batteries, the source of electricity used to charge them, and the overall lifecycle analysis of the vehicle. This paper evaluates the environmental impact of electric vehicles throughout their lifecycle, analyzing their sustainability in terms of carbon emissions, energy use, and the materials used in production. The findings suggest that while electric vehicles are a sustainable alternative to gasoline-powered vehicles, there are still areas for improvement in terms of energy efficiency and responsible material sourcing.
column3: On the Sustainability of Electrical Vehicles

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for estimating the third order intermodulation power for N sinusoidal channels. The proposed method utilizes the Power Spectral Density (PSD) of the input signals and the Intermodulation Product (IM) matrix to estimate the Third Order Intermodulation (TOI) power. The main advantage of this approach is its ability to estimate the TOI power for multiple sinewaves with high accuracy and efficiency. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through simulations, and the results show significant improvement in estimating the TOI power of multiple channels. This technique is useful in the design and characterization of communication systems and may find applications in other fields, including signal processing and network analysis.
column3: Third Order Intermodulation Power Estimation for N Sinusoidal Channels

column1: This paper presents a critical review of the research and innovative design process of a zero-emissions vehicle developed by multidisciplinary student teams over multiple years. The study highlights the challenges encountered in the design process and how they were resolved through collaboration and innovation. The research methodology included a comprehensive literature review, technical feasibility studies, and prototyping to validate the effectiveness of the design. The outcome of this study is a comprehensive report on the design process, which can serve as a guide for future researchers and students in developing zero-emissions vehicles. The multidisciplinary approach to the design process underscores the need for students in different disciplines to work together to achieve common goals in solving real-world problems. Overall, this paper underscores the importance of collaboration, innovation, and dedication to developing efficient zero-emissions vehicles.
column3: Research and innovative design of a zeroemissions vehicle by  multidisciplinary student teams in multi-years

column1: This paper investigates the potential for using commercial building HVAC fans as an ancillary service to support the smart grid. We explore the concept of flexibility, which refers to the ability of HVAC systems to participate in demand response programs that enable the smart grid to balance supply and demand in real-time. We also examine the technical requirements and market opportunities for such a solution, including the potential benefits for both building owners and grid operators. Ultimately, we argue that HVAC flexibility has the potential to play a significant role in the integration of renewables and the optimization of the energy system.
column3: Flexibility of Commercial Building HVAC Fan as Ancillary Service for  Smart Grid

column1: This paper presents analytical studies of the quasi steady-state model in the long-term stability analysis of power systems. The quasi steady-state model, which is an extension of the traditional transient stability model, is used to analyze power systems under various operating conditions. The paper provides a detailed explanation of the quasi steady-state model and its application in long-term stability analysis. Mathematical formulations and algorithms for implementing the quasi steady-state model are presented. Additionally, the paper investigates the performance of the quasi steady-state model using numerical simulations and compares it with other existing models. The results show that the quasi steady-state model provides accurate predictions of long-term stability compared to other models. The findings of this study can be used to improve the accuracy and efficiency of long-term stability analysis in power system planning and operation.
column3: Analytical Studies of Quasi Steady-State Model in Power System Long-Term  Stability Analysis

column1: This paper investigates the effect of battery placement on the performance of VAR controls. The voltage and current waveforms at the point of common coupling (PCC) are analyzed for different placement scenarios of the battery. The results show that the placement of the battery significantly affects the voltage regulation, reactive power compensation, and harmonic mitigation capabilities of the VAR control system. The paper suggests the optimal placement of the battery to enhance the overall performance of the VAR control system.
column3: Battery Placement on Performance of VAR Controls

column1: This paper presents a study on the application of Robust Least Squares (RLS) methods in the presence of data uncertainties that are bounded. The RLS methods aim to minimize the effects of outliers and improve the accuracy of the estimation in regression analysis. The bounded uncertainties considered in this work represent a realistic scenario that arises in many practical applications, such as sensor networks, control systems, and environmental monitoring. The proposed methodology is evaluated through simulations and real-world experiments, demonstrating its effectiveness in handling bounded data uncertainties and providing reliable and accurate estimates in challenging conditions.
column3: Robust Least Squares Methods Under Bounded Data Uncertainties

column1: This paper presents a numerical investigation of the limitations and nonlinear analysis of a quasi steady-state model for voltage stability. The study focuses on the analysis of the model's performance in detecting the risk of voltage instability in power systems. The results obtained from the investigation suggest that the quasi steady-state model may not always be reliable in predicting voltage instability, especially in cases where the power system experiences nonlinear behavior. As a solution to tackle this problem, a nonlinear analysis of the model is proposed to account for the effects of nonlinearities on the behavior of the power system. This research provides valuable insights into the limitations and potential improvements of the quasi steady-state model for voltage stability analysis.
column3: Numerical Investigations on Quasi Steady-State Model for Voltage  Stability: Limitations and Nonlinear Analysis

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for dynamic coupling design to achieve nonlinear output agreement and time-varying flow control in complex systems. The proposed methodology utilizes a combination of state feedback and output feedback controllers, and incorporates a dynamic coupling term to account for system nonlinearities and time-varying disturbances. Through simulation and experimental results, the effectiveness and robustness of the approach are demonstrated, highlighting its potential for widespread application in various engineering fields.
column3: Dynamic coupling design for nonlinear output agreement and time-varying  flow control

column1: The paper Multi-modal filtering for non-linear estimation presents a new approach to estimate non-linear systems using a combination of filtering techniques. The proposed method relies on the fusion of multiple modalities, including measurements from various sensors and prior knowledge about the system dynamics. By integrating these sources of information, the proposed algorithm achieves enhanced accuracy and robustness compared to traditional approaches that rely on a single modality. The paper provides theoretical analysis and empirical evaluation of the proposed method in the context of state estimation for non-linear systems. The results demonstrate that the multi-modal filtering technique offers promising avenues for improving the accuracy and reliability of non-linear estimation in various practical applications.
column3: Multi-modal filtering for non-linear estimation

column1: This paper explores the latest advancements in models for the modern power grid. With the increase in renewable energy sources and the implementation of smart grid technologies, traditional power grid models are no longer sufficient. This paper reviews existing models and proposes new models that consider the complexities of the modern power grid. The paper also discusses the challenges in implementing these models and how they can be used to improve the efficiency and reliability of the power grid. Overall, this paper provides a comprehensive overview of the different models available for the modern power grid and highlights the importance of accurate models for the future of energy systems.
column3: Models for the modern power grid

column1: This paper introduces a novel approach to sparsity-aware adaptive algorithms based on alternating optimization with shrinkage. The proposed method seeks to address the challenges associated with high-dimensional data by iteratively shrinking coefficients towards zero, leading to effective selection of relevant features in the data. The paper provides theoretical insights and practical examples that highlight the advantages of such an approach. Additionally, the paper discusses how this technique can be applied to various domains such as signal processing, machine learning, and image processing, offering a promising avenue for future research in these domains.
column3: Sparsity-Aware Adaptive Algorithms Based on Alternating Optimization  with Shrinkage

column1: This paper presents a new class of Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) distributed observers for LTI plants. The paper establishes the necessary and sufficient conditions for the stabilizability of these observers. The proposed distributed observer uses a network of interconnected sensors to estimate the state of the plant. The stability conditions for the observer are derived using a Lyapunov function approach. The paper also provides simulation results to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed observer. The results show that the observer can achieve accurate state estimation and ensure the stability of the closed-loop system. Overall, the proposed LTI distributed observer provides a promising solution for the estimation and control of LTI plants.
column3: A Class of LTI Distributed Observers for LTI Plants: Necessary and  Sufficient Conditions for Stabilizability

column1: This paper explores the use of numerical simulations in proving abstractions of dynamical systems. We present a method for constructing abstractions that accurately capture the behavior of complex systems, and use numerical simulations to test and validate these abstractions. We then demonstrate the validity of this approach by proving the correctness of abstract models of several real-world systems, including mechanical systems and chemical reactions. Our results suggest that numerical simulations can be an effective tool for validating and refining abstractions of complex systems, and may have important implications for fields such as robotics, control theory, and systems biology.
column3: Proving Abstractions of Dynamical Systems through Numerical Simulations

column1: This paper proposes a discrete-time output-feedback robust repetitive control approach for a class of nonlinear systems. The proposed method uses additive state decomposition to address the issues of nonlinearity and disturbance, ensuring robustness and repetitive tracking performance. Compared to previous methods, the proposed approach requires less information about the system and has a better control performance. The effectiveness and applicability of the proposed method are demonstrated through simulations and experiments on a benchmark system.
column3: Discrete-Time Output-Feedback Robust Repetitive Control for a Class of  Nonlinear Systems by Additive State Decomposition

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for generating internal dynamics in complex systems based on the concept of causal ideals. The proposed method, referred to as the New Causal Ideal Internal Dynamics Generator, allows for the creation of dynamic models that accurately capture the causal relations between various components of the system. The generator is able to incorporate both deterministic and stochastic elements, thereby enabling the modeling of inherently uncertain systems. The paper outlines the theoretical foundation of the approach, as well as its practical implementation and validation through several case studies. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the New Causal Ideal Internal Dynamics Generator in generating accurate and reliable models for a range of complex systems.
column3: A New Causal Ideal Internal Dynamics Generator

column1: This paper proposes the use of a Fuzzy Inference System (FIS) for VOLT/VAR control in distribution substations located in isolated power systems. The FIS is designed to adjust the reactive power output of the distributed generators and capacitor banks, maintaining the bus voltages within the desired limits. The proposed system considers both the steady-state and transient operating conditions of the system and is capable of handling voltage and frequency variations. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed FIS in controlling the VOLT/VAR within the acceptable range for an isolated power system, improving the overall performance and reliability of the system.
column3: Fuzzy Inference System for VOLT/VAR control in distribution substations  in isolated power systems

column1: This paper presents a study on equivalent relaxations of optimal power flow, which is a challenging problem in the field of power systems. The paper explores different relaxations and their performance in solving the optimal power flow problem. Specifically, the paper introduces a new relaxation technique that improves the computational efficiency of solving the problem. The effectiveness of the proposed relaxation is demonstrated through experiments on IEEE benchmark systems. The results suggest that the proposed relaxation approach can significantly reduce the computational time while maintaining the accuracy of the solution. This study contributes to the development of efficient and reliable algorithms for optimal power flow in modern power systems.
column3: Equivalent relaxations of optimal power flow

column1: This paper proposes a scenario-based control design approach for non-convex systems, which involves modeling uncertain system dynamics as a set of scenarios that represent possible future trajectories of the system. The method uses a robust optimization framework that considers worst-case scenarios to design the control inputs. The proposed method is shown to be effective in controlling non-convex systems with uncertain dynamics, and is validated through simulations on a real-world system. Our results demonstrate the advantages of scenario-based approaches for non-convex control design and highlight the potential for future research in this area.
column3: A scenario approach for non-convex control design

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach to back-pressure traffic signal control in urban intersection networks with unknown or variable routing rates. The back-pressure control guarantees optimal performance in terms of minimizing delay and maximizing throughput, but typically relies on the assumption of known routing rates. To overcome this limitation, we apply statistical inference techniques to estimate the routing rates from observed traffic data at the intersection. We then incorporate these estimates into a back-pressure control algorithm that adapts in real-time to changes in traffic conditions. Our simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in improving traffic efficiency and reducing congestion in a network of intersection nodes.
column3: Back-pressure traffic signal control with unknown routing rates

column1: This paper presents an analysis of the swarm stability of linear time-invariant descriptor compartmental networks. Theoretical frameworks for analyzing the stability of such networks are introduced, and stability criteria are derived. These stability criteria are utilized to provide insights into the dynamics of these networks, and to determine the conditions under which they will exhibit stable behavior. The paper contributes to the understanding of the behavior of linear time-invariant descriptor compartmental networks, and provides a foundation for the design and analysis of practical networks in a variety of contexts.
column3: On Swarm Stability of Linear Time-Invariant Descriptor Compartmental  Networks

column1: This paper presents a novel algorithm for robust recursive state estimation with random measurement droppings. The objective is to estimate the state of a system using sensor measurements while accounting for the intermittently missing measurements due to unreliable sensors or communication channels. The proposed algorithm employs a recursive Bayesian filter and incorporates a statistical model of the measurement dropout process. Simulation results show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and robustness in various scenarios with intermittent measurements.
column3: Robust Recursive State Estimation with Random Measurements Droppings

column1: This paper presents a complexity analysis of heuristic pulse interleaving algorithms for multi-target tracking with multiple simultaneous receive beams. The study explores the performance of these algorithms in terms of computational complexity and accuracy, and evaluates their effectiveness in different scenarios. The results of this analysis provide insights into the strengths and limitations of these algorithms and offer guidance for improving their design and implementation. Overall, this study contributes to the advancement of pulse interleaving algorithms for multi-target tracking, which is crucial for various applications, such as radar and sonar systems.
column3: Complexity Analysis of Heuristic Pulse Interleaving Algorithms for  Multi-Target Tracking with Multiple Simultaneous Receive Beams

column1: The nuclear norm subspace identification (N2SID) method has been widely used for system identification of dynamic systems with large datasets. However, its effectiveness on short data batches is not well established. In this paper, we propose an extension of the N2SID method for short data batches by incorporating a regularization framework. The proposed method is able to identify the underlying system dynamics even with short data batches, and outperforms existing subspace methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. Numerical experiments on simulated and real-world datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, indicating its potential for various applications in engineering and science.
column3: Nuclear Norm Subspace Identification (N2SID) for short data batches

column1: This paper aims to explore the controllability and observability of networked dynamic systems. The study investigates the influence of network topology on the controllability and observability of the system through the use of graph theory and distributed control techniques. The paper also discusses the importance of understanding these properties in designing effective control and monitoring strategies for complex networked systems. Ultimately, this research provides valuable insights into how to enhance the performance and reliability of networked dynamic systems in various domains.
column3: On the Controllability and Observability of Networked Dynamic Systems

column1: This paper presents a stability analysis and design approach for a network of event-based systems. The proposed approach considers the interconnection among individual systems in the network and investigates their dynamical behavior. A Lyapunov-based stability criterion is derived to ensure the stability of the network. Moreover, a design method is proposed to optimize the network performance, taking into account the interconnection topology and system parameters. The feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed approach are demonstrated through a numerical example. The results indicate that the proposed stability analysis and design approach can effectively improve the stability and performance of the network of event-based systems.
column3: Stability Analysis and Design of a Network of Event-based Systems

column1: This paper explores the concept of using conformance testing as a means of falsification for cyber-physical systems. Specifically, it discusses how conformance testing can help identify system anomalies and determine the limits of system functionality through the generation of test cases that intentionally deviate from expected behavior. Through this approach, this paper argues that conformance testing can serve as an effective tool for enhancing the safety and reliability of cyber-physical systems. The paper also provides examples of how conformance testing has been applied in real-world scenarios to successfully identify and mitigate potential system failures. Overall, this paper highlights the importance of using conformance testing as a means of falsification to ensure the safety, reliability, and security of cyber-physical systems.
column3: Conformance Testing as Falsification for Cyber-Physical Systems

column1: This paper investigates the controllability and near-controllability properties of two-dimensional multi-input discrete-time bilinear systems. The study focuses on the analysis of the system matrices and their inherent properties to establish necessary and sufficient conditions for controllability and near-controllability. A detailed theoretical analysis is carried out, and the obtained results are illustrated through numerical simulations. The findings of this study can be useful in the design and control of bilinear systems, especially in the fields of control engineering and robotics.
column3: On Controllability and Near-controllability of Multi-input Discrete-time  Bilinear Systems in Dimension Two

column1: This paper explores the dynamics of flows over time in time-varying networks. It presents a model for analyzing such flows using a time-continuous formulation that takes into account both temporal and spatial variations. The paper discusses the mathematical properties of the model, and provides algorithms for solving it using simulation and optimization techniques. It also presents several applications of the model to real-world systems such as transportation networks, social networks and wireless communication networks. The paper concludes by highlighting the important implications of these findings for network design and management in time-varying environments.
column3: Flows over time in time-varying networks

column1: This paper presents a root locus approach for studying the near-controllability, nearly-controllable subspaces, and near-controllability index of a class of discrete-time bilinear systems. The paper begins by defining the notion of near-controllability and nearly-controllable subspaces. The root locus approach is then developed and applied to analyze the near-controllability properties of the system. The results obtained are used to assess the robustness of the system against external disturbances. The paper concludes that the root locus approach provides a powerful tool for studying the near-controllability properties of bilinear systems, and can be used for system design and control applications.
column3: On Near-controllability, Nearly-controllable Subspaces, and  Near-controllability Index of a Class of Discrete-time Bilinear Systems: A  Root Locus Approach

column1: The paper 'Wind Turbine Model and Observer in Takagi-Sugeno Model Structure' proposes a new modeling and observer design approach for wind turbines based on the Takagi-Sugeno model structure. The proposed model consists of a nonlinear wind turbine model and a set of local linear submodels, which can be used for control and observer design. Additionally, a new observer design approach based on the high-gain observer is developed to estimate the unmeasured states of the system. The proposed approach is demonstrated using simulation results, which show improved tracking performance compared to conventional observer designs. The results suggest that the proposed approach could be applicable for real-time wind turbine control systems.
column3: Wind Turbine Model and Observer in Takagi-Sugeno Model Structure

column1: This paper examines the phenomenon of cascading failures in power grids and presents a comprehensive analysis of the causes and effects of these failures. The paper discusses the different algorithms conventionally used for detecting and mitigating cascading failures, and evaluates their effectiveness in addressing the issue. The study also introduces novel algorithms that use advanced techniques such as graph theory and machine learning to enhance the accuracy and efficiency of cascade prediction and control. The paper concludes with a discussion on the potential application of these algorithms in real-world power grid systems, and the future research avenues that could further enhance our understanding of cascading failures.
column3: Cascading Failures in Power Grids - Analysis and Algorithms

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach to modeling switched behavior using hybrid bond graph, applied to a tank system. Switched behavior refers to a system that exhibits multiple modes of operation, often switching between them based on certain conditions. The hybrid bond graph framework provides a unified approach to modeling the continuous and discrete dynamics of such systems. The tank system is used as a case study to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. Simulations are conducted to demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of the model in capturing the behavior of the tank system under different operating modes. The results of this study provide insights into the applicability of hybrid bond graph modeling in capturing the complexity of switched behavior in engineering systems.
column3: Modeling Switched Behavior with Hybrid Bond Graph: Application to a Tank  system

column1: This paper presents a novel approach to moving horizon estimation by utilizing multiple windows. The proposed Multiple Window Moving Horizon Estimation (MW-MHE) method offers advantages over traditional single-window methods by allowing for the inclusion of prior knowledge and enabling the detection of abrupt changes in the system. The MW-MHE approach is validated through simulation studies on various systems, demonstrating superior performance over existing methods. This paper contributes to the literature on moving horizon estimation and offers a promising direction for future research in the field.
column3: Multiple Window Moving Horizon Estimation

column1: This paper presents an improved design method for nearly linear-phase IIR filters using constrained optimization. The proposed method employs a weighted least-squares optimization technique with additional constraints, which results in an enhanced filter performance while maintaining the nearly linear-phase characteristic. The algorithmic steps and optimization criteria are presented, and the proposed method's efficiency is demonstrated through comparative analysis with traditional IIR filter design methods. Simulation results show that the improved design method provides a better trade-off between passband ripple and stopband attenuation, effectively reducing the overall filter complexity. The proposed method has potential applications in a variety of digital signal processing systems, including audio and image processing, communication systems, and biomedical instrumentation.
column3: Improved Design Method for Nearly Linear-Phase IIR Filters Using  Constrained Optimization

column1: This paper proposes a method for simulating and bisimulating behaviors over multiple time scales. The approach involves partitioning the behavior into discrete stages, each with its own time scale, and using a combination of simulation and bisimulation techniques to analyze the system. We illustrate our method with a case study of a multi-stage system, demonstrating its effectiveness in accurately capturing the dynamics of complex behavior. This approach has broad applicability in fields such as robotics, control, and artificial intelligence.
column3: Simulation and Bisimulation over Multiple Time Scales in a Behavioral  Setting

column1: This paper explores the implementation of fuzzy logic for temperature control in various systems. The use of fuzzy logic allows for a more dynamic approach to temperature control, leading to improved performance and energy efficiency. The paper begins with an overview of fuzzy logic and its applications in temperature control, followed by a review of current research in this field. A fuzzy logic controller is then designed and simulated, and its performance is compared to that of a traditional PID controller. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of fuzzy logic in temperature control, highlighting its ability to respond to changing conditions and maintain stability in complex systems. Overall, this paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the advantages of fuzzy logic in temperature control and its potential for practical implementation in various industries.
column3: Temperature Control using Fuzzy Logic

column1: This paper proposes a novel method to parametrize the completeness of symbolic abstraction for bounded input linear systems. The proposed approach utilizes an over-approximation technique to derive a set of necessary and sufficient conditions for parametrization. The completeness parametrization is then illustrated on examples to showcase its efficacy in reducing the conservatism associated with symbolic abstraction. The proposed method is expected to aid in the development of a wide variety of control and verification algorithms for linear systems.
column3: Parametrization of completeness in symbolic abstraction of bounded input  linear systems

column1: This paper explores the application of the Pseudo-Transient Continuation (PTC) method in dynamic stability analysis. The PTC method is a numerical technique that can accurately simulate the behavior of a dynamic system with a wide range of initial conditions. In this study, the PTC method is applied to analyze the dynamic stability of a power system under various operating conditions. The results show that the PTC method provides a reliable and efficient approach to analyzing dynamic stability problems in power systems. It is concluded that the PTC method has significant potential for further exploration in dynamic stability analysis.
column3: Application of Pseudo-Transient Continuation Method in Dynamic Stability  Analysis

column1: The accurate estimation of parameters in an induction motor is crucial for proper monitoring and control of the system. In this paper, a new method based on the artificial bee colony algorithm is proposed for parameter estimation in induction motors. The algorithm provides an efficient way of searching for optimal parameter values, resulting in more accurate and reliable estimations. Simulation results show that the proposed method outperforms traditional techniques, demonstrating its effectiveness as a promising approach for accurate parameter estimation in induction motors.
column3: New Method for Accurate Parameter Estimation of Induction Motors Based  on Artificial Bee Colony Algorithm

column1: The paper titled Minimizing Running Costs in Consumption Systems explores various strategies for reducing energy usage and overall running costs in consumption systems. This study highlights the importance of energy efficiency as a key factor in lowering operational costs and reducing environmental impact. The paper presents several case studies that demonstrate effective measures for minimizing power consumption, including the use of smart technologies, optimization of energy storage systems, and monitoring and management of energy usage levels. The findings of this paper provide valuable insights into how consumption systems can be made more sustainable, efficient, and cost-effective.
column3: Minimizing Running Costs in Consumption Systems

column1: The uncertainty principle represents a fundamental barrier to the accuracy and predictability of physical systems, with applications throughout the natural sciences. In this paper, we explore the implications of the uncertainty principle for the field of control theory, a vital area of study for the design and operation of feedback control systems. We develop a comprehensive analysis of the performance limitations imposed by the uncertainty principle, exploring both the theoretical underpinnings of this fundamental principle and its practical impact on the design and performance of control systems. Our results offer valuable insights and guidance for optimizing the operation of feedback control systems in the presence of uncertainty, providing a basis for further research and development in this important field. Overall, this paper represents a significant contribution to the ongoing effort to understand and overcome the limitations of control theory in the face of fundamental physical constraints.
column3: Uncertainty Principle in Control Theory, Part I: Analysis of Performance  Limitations

column1: This paper presents a computational study on the collective oscillation period of inter-coupled biological negative cyclic feedback oscillators. The aim is to investigate the effects of interconnection strength and parameter variability on the synchronization behavior of the oscillators. Results suggest that the oscillators can exhibit different synchronized behaviors, depending on the parameters and coupling strength values. It is also observed that parameter variability can lead to desynchronization in the collective behavior of the system. Overall, this study offers insights into the collective behavior of biological oscillators, which may be useful in understanding complex biological systems.
column3: Collective oscillation period of inter-coupled biological negative  cyclic feedback oscillators

column1: This paper presents an innovative approach to control the motion of free-floating space manipulators using adaptive zero reaction control. The proposed methodology utilizes a set of motion equations to predict the motion of the manipulator and compensates for reaction torques that arise when the manipulator moves in free space. The control parameters are optimized through an adaptive algorithm that ensures the system's stability and accuracy. The results of the simulation show that the proposed method significantly improves the manipulator's performance, reducing the reaction torque and achieving more precise and stable motion control during the manipulation of external payloads. The approach represents an important contribution to the development of space robotics, enabling more efficient and reliable control of free-floating space manipulators.
column3: Adaptive Zero Reaction Motion Control for Free-Floating Space  Manipulators

column1: This paper presents a formal specification and a quantitative analysis of a constellation of navigation satellites. The formal specification provides a systematic approach for modeling the behavior of the satellites and ensuring their correctness. The quantitative analysis utilizes probabilistic methods to assess the performance of the constellation in terms of accuracy, availability, and reliability. The results demonstrate that the proposed constellation design is effective and efficient for providing accurate and reliable global navigation services. This study contributes to the formal methods and probabilistic modeling communities by demonstrating the usefulness of these techniques in the design and analysis of complex systems such as satellite constellations.
column3: Formal Specification and Quantitative Analysis of a Constellation of  Navigation Satellites

column1: This paper proposes a three-dimensional integrated guidance and control approach based on the small-gain theorem. The integrated guidance and control system is designed to achieve target tracking and stabilization in three-dimensional space for multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The small-gain theorem provides a framework for analyzing the stability and robustness of the integrated system in the presence of uncertainties and disturbances. Simulation results confirm the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed approach for multi-UAV applications. The paper provides potential directions for future research in combining guidance and control for complex tasks in three-dimensional space.
column3: Three-Dimensional Integrated Guidance and Control Based on Small-Gain  Theorem

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach to containment control in a social network with state-dependent connectivity. The objective of this study is to explore the behavior of a group of agents in a social network where the interactions between agents vary over time. The proposed containment control framework ensures that a subset of agents converge to a desired state while controlling the number of interactions between agents. The analysis of the proposed approach is supported by simulations, demonstrating its effectiveness in achieving containment control in a social network with varying connectivity. This paper presents a significant contribution to the field of social network analysis by introducing an innovative approach to control the spread of information and limit the number of interactions between agents.
column3: Containment Control for a Social Network with State-Dependent  Connectivity

column1: This paper presents a decentralized control scheme for a multi-agent system with network connectivity constraints using navigation functions. The proposed control methodology ensures each agent's stability and convergence to its goal while preventing collisions and keeping the group connected. A set of geometric navigation functions are utilized to construct a distributed control law that guides each agent towards its goal position, while avoiding obstacles and maintaining communication with its neighbors. The effectiveness of the proposed control scheme is validated through simulation results, showing the system's overall stability, scalability, and adaptability to the constraints imposed by the network topology. The proposed approach has significant implications for multi-robot systems operating in complex environments with limited communication and computational resources.
column3: Navigation Function Based Decentralized Control of A Multi-Agent System  with Network Connectivity Constraints

column1: This paper proposes a decentralized hybrid formation control approach for multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The approach combines the strengths of both the leader-follower and the behavior-based formation control methods, resulting in improved formation stability, scalability, and flexibility. The proposed approach also allows for efficient communication among the UAVs and does not rely on a centralized controller, increasing the robustness of the system. Simulations conducted on a group of UAVs validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, demonstrating the ability to maintain a desired formation even in the presence of disturbances and uncertainties.
column3: Decentralized Hybrid Formation Control of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles

column1: This paper explores the relationship between compression learning and scenario-based optimization, both emerging techniques in the field of data analytics. Compression learning promises to improve data analysis by reducing the dimensionality of data, whereas scenario-based optimization aims to find solutions to complex optimization problems by considering multiple possible scenarios. Through a comprehensive review of literature and case studies, this paper reveals the potential for these two techniques to complement each other in various applications. It also presents a framework that integrates compression learning and scenario-based optimization to achieve more robust and efficient optimization solutions. Overall, the study highlights the importance of considering multiple perspectives and methodologies in data analysis and optimization.
column3: On the connection between compression learning and scenario based  optimization

column1: This paper proposes a new method for model reduction of linear switched systems using moment matching. The approach involves reducing the model order by matching the moments of the input-output responses of the original and reduced models. The proposed method is applied to linear switched systems with varying switching modes and the simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the method in achieving accurate model reduction while retaining key system properties. The method has potential applications in areas such as control system design and optimization, where reduced-order models are required for faster and more efficient analysis.
column3: Model Reduction by Moment Matching for Linear Switched Systems

column1: This paper proposes a method for the credible autocoding of convex optimization algorithms. The approach ensures the reliability of the software by verifying the accuracy of the auto-generated code against the original algorithm through multiple tests. This paper presents the methodology and provides experimental results to demonstrate its effectiveness in providing accurate and reliable software for convex optimization problems. The proposed method represents a significant step towards automating the software development process, reducing errors, and saving time and resources.
column3: Credible Autocoding of Convex Optimization Algorithms

column1: This paper explores the global synchronization of pulse-coupled oscillators on cycle graphs. The study includes an analysis of the coupling strengths and the effects of the network structure on the emergence of synchronization. Results show that cycle graphs with a small circumference and high degree of symmetry facilitate the global synchronization of the oscillators. The study provides valuable insights into the conditions necessary for the synchronous behavior of pulse-coupled oscillators on cycle graphs, which have numerous applications in various fields.
column3: Global Synchronization of Pulse-Coupled Oscillators Interacting on Cycle  Graphs

column1: This paper proposes a composable method for real-time control of active distribution networks with explicit power setpoints. The method provides a flexible and modular approach to control the power flow in distributed energy resources, such as solar panels and wind turbines, to meet the desired power setpoints of the network. The proposed approach is designed to be scalable and adaptable to different network sizes and configurations, while also ensuring real-time response and robustness in the presence of uncertainty and disturbances. The effectiveness of the method is demonstrated through simulation studies using actual distribution networks, and the results show improved performance compared to existing control methods.
column3: A Composable Method for Real-Time Control of Active Distribution  Networks with Explicit Power Setpoints

column1: This paper presents the development of a model predictive HVAC control strategy with an online occupancy model. This approach combines occupancy prediction and feedback control to enable an HVAC system to operate more efficiently while maintaining occupant comfort. The proposed method employs a deep learning-based online occupancy model to predict occupancy in real-time, which is then used to optimize HVAC operations using a model predictive control strategy. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach can significantly improve the efficiency of the HVAC system while maintaining a high level of occupant comfort. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is assessed using real-world data obtained from an office building. The presented method provides a practical and effective solution for reducing energy consumption and operating costs of HVAC systems in commercial buildings.
column3: Model Predictive HVAC Control with Online Occupancy Model

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach to the stabilization of sampled-data switched linear systems using quantized feedback control. The study shows that the proposed method can overcome various issues associated with conventional control techniques, such as limited communication bandwidth and quantization errors. The mathematical formalism of the method is rigorously developed, and its effectiveness is demonstrated through simulation studies on a range of benchmark systems. The results show that the proposed method can provide effective control even in the presence of measurement noise and quantization errors, making it a promising approach to the control of complex switched linear systems.
column3: Quantized Feedback Stabilization of Sampled-Data Switched Linear Systems

column1: This paper proposes a novel technique for model reduction of physical network systems based on clustering, while preserving their underlying structure. The proposed approach combines graph clustering and model order reduction to group interrelated network nodes and reduce computational complexity. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through various physical network systems, including power systems and multi-agent systems. The results show that the proposed approach provides effective model reduction while retaining the essential behavior of the original system.
column3: Structure-preserving model reduction of physical network systems by  clustering

column1: Distributed System Identification with ADMM presents a novel approach to identify complex systems using the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) algorithm. This paper proposes a distributed framework that enables multiple agents to accurately estimate system parameters in a decentralized manner. The proposed method is validated on several simulations and real-world applications to demonstrate its effectiveness compared to other conventional methods. Overall, this paper offers a comprehensive insight into the application of ADMM in distributed system identification, paving the way for scalable and accurate distributed estimation in the future.
column3: Distributed System Identification with ADMM

column1: This paper investigates the problem of optimally providing regulation service reserves under dynamic energy service preferences. We propose a mathematical model that considers the dynamic nature of energy consumption and allows for the incorporation of real-time demand-response mechanisms. The model is capable of optimizing the use of resources and balancing the trade-off between energy service preferences and regulatory requirements. Our approach contributes to the development of efficient strategies for managing regulation service reserves in the presence of varying energy consumption patterns. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of our model in mitigating the impact of uncertain demand and supply conditions on power system stability, while achieving optimal regulation reserve use.
column3: Optimal Provision of Regulation Service Reserves Under Dynamic Energy  Service Preferences

column1: The paper titled Zero Forcing Sets and Controllability of Dynamical Systems Defined on Graphs explores the relationship between zero forcing sets and the controllability of dynamical systems on graphs. The concept of zero forcing sets has emerged as a powerful tool in the study of network control and is closely related to the controllability of dynamical systems. The paper presents a detailed analysis of the properties of zero forcing sets in graphs and their impact on the controllability of corresponding dynamical systems. The theoretical findings are supported by numerical simulations, which demonstrate how the concept of zero forcing sets can be used to design control strategies for complex networked systems. The results have significant implications for the design of efficient control algorithms for large-scale systems and suggest new approaches for achieving desired target behaviors.
column3: Zero forcing sets and controllability of dynamical systems defined on  graphs

column1: This paper proposes an efficient and variational approach for approximating the best fitting multi-Bernoulli filter, which has become an essential technique in modern tracking systems. The proposed method combines a variational approximation and a novel gradient ascent technique, resulting in a highly accurate and computationally efficient estimation of the multi-Bernoulli filter. Experimental evaluations on real-world data sets demonstrate the superior performance and computational efficiency of the proposed method compared to state-of-the-art methods. Overall, the proposed approach provides a promising solution for accurate and efficient multi-object tracking.
column3: An efficient, variational approximation of the best fitting  multi-Bernoulli filter

column1: This paper presents a novel approach to saliency-based control in random feature networks. The proposed method utilizes saliency maps generated from input images to facilitate real-time control in a robotic system. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through extensive simulations on multiple datasets. Our results indicate that saliency-based control significantly enhances the performance of random feature networks in object recognition tasks. We discuss the potential applications of saliency-based control in diverse fields such as autonomous driving, robotics, and surveillance systems.
column3: Saliency Based Control in Random Feature Networks

column1: This paper explores the Lyapunov concept of stability through the lens of the Poincare approach. It presents a general procedure for utilizing Lyapunov functions in the analysis of non-linear, non-autonomous parametric differential inclusions. The paper discusses the advantages of choosing Lyapunov functions that are closely related to the boundary conditions of the given system. Through mathematical analysis and experimental data, the paper demonstrates the effectiveness of this approach in determining the stability properties of such complex systems. The findings of this research contribute to advancing our understanding of the Lyapunov concept of stability, and provide a valuable tool for researchers in a wide range of fields.
column3: The Lyapunov Concept of Stability from the Standpoint of Poincare  Approach: General Procedure of Utilization of Lyapunov Functions for  Non-Linear Non-Autonomous Parametric Differential Inclusions

column1: This paper presents a study of a step and search control method applied to wind energy conversion systems for tracking the maximum power. The proposed method is designed to enhance the performance of the control system in terms of the accuracy and speed of power tracking. The system's model is presented with the mathematical equations and modeled in Matlab/Simulink. The simulation results show that the proposed method outperforms the conventional control methods. The proposed method produces a stable and fast response to changing wind speeds and yields efficient power generation in low and high winds. The step and search control method is a promising approach for improving the performance of wind energy conversion systems.
column3: Step and Search Control Method to Track the Maximum Power in Wind Energy  Conversion Systems A Study

column1: This paper explores the concept of applications-oriented input design in time-domain analysis through cyclic methods. The goal of this research is to develop a practical approach for designing inputs that can be used to study the dynamic behavior of different types of structures and systems. The study methodology is based on a multi-objective optimization framework that aims to find the optimal input signal that can maximize the information content while minimizing the input energy. The results show that the proposed method is effective in generating input signals that can effectively identify the dynamic behavior of structures and systems under different loading conditions. Additionally, the study provides a comprehensive analysis of the trade-offs between the input energy and the information content of the signal, which can help researchers to select the appropriate input signals to use in their experiments. Overall, this paper contributes to the field of input design and provides a useful framework for designing applications-oriented inputs in time-domain analysis.
column3: Applications Oriented Input Design in Time-Domain Through Cyclic Methods

column1: The analysis of hybrid systems is crucial in many fields, such as control and automation. In this paper, we propose a method for abstracting elementary hybrid systems by variable transformation, which reduces the complexity of the system and enables efficient analysis. Our approach allows for the identification of critical variables that can be used to capture the system's behavior and provide a simplified abstract model, while preserving important properties such as safety and reachability. We illustrate the effectiveness of our method with examples from various domains, including robotics and power systems. Our results demonstrate the advantages of our approach in terms of scalability and computational efficiency.
column3: Abstraction of Elementary Hybrid Systems by Variable Transformation

column1: This paper presents a new approach for the direct design of LPV (Linear Parameter-Varying) feedback controllers, which are capable of achieving high performance while accommodating changes in operating conditions. The technical details of this approach are discussed, including the use of linear matrix inequalities and convex optimization techniques. A series of numerical examples are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed approach. The results show that the LPV controllers designed using this method exhibit superior performance compared to traditional controllers, with improved robustness to system uncertainties and disturbances. Overall, this paper provides valuable insights for engineers seeking to design high-performance feedback controllers for LPV systems.
column3: Direct design of LPV feedback controllers: technical details and  numerical examples

column1: This paper discusses the design of symbolic controllers for networked control systems. Symbolic controllers are well-suited for controlling complex systems due to their ability to handle complex relationships between variables. The paper explores the challenges of designing symbolic controllers for networked control systems and proposes a solution that uses model-based methods to design controllers that can operate effectively in a networked environment. The proposed approach is evaluated through simulations, and the results demonstrate its effectiveness in controlling networked systems. This paper provides valuable insights into the design of symbolic controllers for networked systems and presents a practical solution that can be applied to real-world scenarios.
column3: Design of Symbolic Controllers for Networked Control Systems

column1: This paper explores the concept of duration-differentiated services in the electricity sector. It discusses the benefits of offering different electricity services for different durations, including the potential for more efficient use of resources and increased customer satisfaction. The paper examines various approaches to implementing duration-differentiated services in electricity, including time-of-use pricing and dynamic demand response. It also highlights some of the challenges and potential obstacles to adoption, including regulatory barriers and technological limitations. Ultimately, the paper argues that duration differentiation has the potential to transform the electricity sector into a more flexible and customer-oriented industry.
column3: Duration-Differentiated Services in Electricity

column1: This paper presents a novel approach to analyze consensus protocols for dynamic graph networks using the concept of persistence. Our approach can determine the robustness of the consensus protocol and identify the persistent topological features that contribute to its stability. We validate our methodology on various consensus protocols and demonstrate its effectiveness in identifying the persistent topological features in the network. Our results highlight the importance of considering persistence-based metrics for analyzing consensus protocols in dynamic graph networks.
column3: Persistence based analysis of consensus protocols for dynamic graph  networks

column1: The paper focuses on the application of Model Predictive Control (MPC) to a coupled tank liquid level system. The objective is to design and implement MPC to regulate the level of liquid in each tank by manipulating the flow rate between them. Mathematical models of the system are developed and used as inputs to the MPC optimizer. Simulation results show that the MPC controller provides a significantly improved performance compared to traditional control strategies. Additionally, various scenarios are evaluated to demonstrate the robustness of the MPC controller in the face of different disturbances and setpoint changes. Overall, the paper presents a practical approach to control complex, nonlinear systems using MPC.
column3: Model Predictive Control (MPC) Applied To Coupled Tank Liquid Level  System

column1: This paper discusses the importance of capturing aggregate flexibility in demand response as a means of balancing the grid in the current energy landscape. Studying the relationship between demand response and the power system, we analyze how a more accurate capturing of aggregate flexibility can increase grid stability and support the integration of renewable energy. Using a case study, we demonstrate how strategies for capturing aggregate flexibility can be implemented in existing demand response programs, highlighting the potential for more effective and efficient demand response management.
column3: Capturing Aggregate Flexibility in Demand Response

column1: This paper presents a proposed framework for scalable and anonymous modeling of large populations of flexible appliances. The framework is intended to be an efficient and effective way to model the behavior of large groups of flexible appliances and to protect the privacy of individuals. The paper discusses the challenges of modeling such large populations and the specific features of the proposed framework that address these challenges. The paper also includes a detailed analysis of the privacy protections provided by the framework and outlines possible applications of the framework in various contexts. Overall, this paper presents a promising approach to modeling large populations of flexible appliances in a way that balances accuracy, scalability, and privacy.
column3: Scalable and Anonymous Modeling of Large Populations of Flexible  Appliances

column1: This paper proposes a new evaluation metric for multi-object tracking systems called the Labelled Optimal Sub-pattern Assignment (OSPA) metric for fixed and known number of targets. The proposed metric takes into account the labels of the tracked objects, enabling a more accurate and informative assessment of tracking performance. This metric is compared to traditional OSPA metrics and evaluated on a real-world dataset showing its superiority in assessing tracking systems with known target numbers. The results suggest that the proposed Labelled OSPA metric can provide a more comprehensive evaluation tool for multi-object tracking systems with known target numbers.
column3: Labelled OSPA metric for fixed and known number of targets

column1: In this paper, we propose an Approximate Minimum Mean Square Error (MMSE) estimator for Linear Dynamic Systems with Gaussian Mixture Noise. We derive the optimal linear filter and approximation algorithm for the MMSE estimator, and demonstrate its effectiveness compared to existing methods through simulations. Our proposed estimator provides a practical solution for the estimation of linear dynamic systems with Gaussian mixture noise, which is commonly encountered in many real-world applications.
column3: Approximate MMSE Estimator for Linear Dynamic Systems with Gaussian  Mixture Noise

column1: This paper proposes a robust dynamic state feedback guaranteed cost control scheme for nonlinear systems using copies of plant nonlinearities. The proposed method aims to improve the robustness and stability of the system by introducing additional state variables that represent the plant nonlinearities. The control is designed to minimize the guaranteed cost, which is a measure of the worst-case performance of the system. Simulations and comparative studies demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed scheme over existing control methods under various operating conditions. The results show that the proposed method can improve the closed-loop performance and robustness of the system, making it suitable for practical applications.
column3: Robust Dynamic State Feedback Guaranteed Cost Control of Nonlinear  Systems using Copies of Plant Nonlinearities

column1: This paper proposes a new method for nonparametric infinite horizon Kullback-Leibler stochastic control. The method is implemented using a dynamic programming approach and utilizes the Kullback-Leibler divergence to measure dissimilarity between probability distributions. The proposed method does not require any knowledge of the underlying system dynamics or the functional form of the cost function. Numerical simulations demonstrate the efficacy and practicality of the proposed approach in various control problems. The results suggest that the nonparametric infinite horizon Kullback-Leibler stochastic control may provide a useful tool for solving complex stochastic control problems without requiring parametric assumptions.
column3: Nonparametric Infinite Horizon Kullback-Leibler Stochastic Control

column1: This paper proposes a modified linear iterative method for the linearization of time-varying nonlinear systems. The approach is based on a set of linear differential equations and a series of linear feedback controllers, which are designed iteratively to approximate the nonlinearities of the original system. The algorithm is shown to converge quickly to a fixed point and to provide accurate linear approximations of time-varying nonlinear systems. The efficacy of the proposed method is demonstrated through numerical simulations of several nonlinear systems, under various conditions, thereby highlighting its potential in a range of practical applications.
column3: Linearization of Time-Varying Nonlinear Systems Using A Modified Linear  Iterative Method

column1: This paper presents a study on the use of electric impedance as a means of determining the functional state of fruits. By analyzing the electrical properties of fruits, such as conductivity and resistance, the functional state of the fruit can be determined. This study includes experiments conducted on different types of fruits with varying degrees of ripeness, and the results show a strong correlation between the electrical impedance parameters and the functional state of the fruit. The findings of this research have potential implications for the agricultural industry, as they offer a non-invasive and efficient method for assessing fruit quality and ripeness.
column3: Determination of the functional state of the fruits by parameters of the  electric impedance

column1: This paper addresses the problem of computing an optimal control policy for an energy storage system. The use of energy storage is becoming increasingly important as renewable energy sources become more prevalent. However, optimizing the control policy of an energy storage system is a complex task due to the dynamic nature of energy supply and demand. This paper proposes a framework for computing an optimal control policy using model predictive control (MPC) and dynamic programming (DP). Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, which can improve the performance of energy storage systems and facilitate the integration of renewable energy sources into the grid.
column3: Computing an Optimal Control Policy for an Energy Storage

column1: This paper explores the implementation of Diffusion LMS (Least Mean Square) over multitask networks. Diffusion LMS is a distributed algorithm that is widely used for network optimization applications. The multitask network is a type of network that can handle multiple tasks simultaneously. The objective of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of Diffusion LMS over multitask networks and to compare it with the traditional LMS algorithm. The results show that Diffusion LMS over multitask networks outperforms the traditional LMS algorithm in terms of convergence speed and accuracy. The study also discusses the potential applications of the proposed algorithm in complex network optimization problems.
column3: Diffusion LMS over Multitask Networks

column1: This paper presents a novel design of a capacitor-less low-dropout voltage regulator (LDO) that achieves high performance with reduced area, improved efficiency and high stability. The proposed circuit operates by replacing the conventional output capacitor with a feedforward path that generates a small signal to compensate for load and line variations. A frequency compensation technique is also employed to ensure stable operation while maintaining a low cutoff frequency. Experimental results show that the proposed LDO achieves a low dropout voltage of 125mV with a maximum load current of 100mA, while occupying a small chip area of 0.03mm². The proposed design is suitable for battery-powered or mobile applications where area and efficiency are critical design considerations.
column3: Design of a capacitor-less low-dropout voltage regulator

column1: This paper presents an analysis of the limitations of the quasi steady-state model (QSSM) for power system stability and proposes a remedy. The QSSM has been widely used for modeling power systems due to its simplicity and computational efficiency. However, it is known to veer away from the actual system behavior during transient conditions, leading to inaccuracies in stability analysis. The authors identify the cases where QSSM limitations can result in incorrect stability assessment and propose a remedy based on extending the QSSM with additional dynamic equations. The proposed remedy is evaluated on a realistic test system, and the results show significant improvement in predicting the system behavior during transient conditions. This study highlights the importance of addressing the limitations of QSSM to ensure accurate stability analysis of power systems.
column3: Quasi Steady-State Model for Power System Stability: Limitations,  Analysis and a Remedy

column1: This paper explores the use of abstractions and sensor design in the synthesis of partial-information, reactive controllers. The goal is to develop a method for the efficient and effective creation of these controllers in complex systems. The paper presents a new approach that utilizes abstraction techniques to reduce the complexity of the system, which in turn improves the design of the accompanying sensors. The resulting controllers are demonstrated to be highly effective in a range of scenarios, making this approach a valuable tool in the creation of advanced control systems. The findings of this study have important implications for the design of future systems that require partial-information, reactive controllers.
column3: Abstractions and sensor design in partial-information, reactive  controller synthesis

column1: This paper presents a cyber-physical testbed for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) that is low-cost and easily accessible. The testbed is designed to allow researchers and students to experiment with various UAV control and sensing methods without the need for expensive hardware or extensive technical knowledge. The paper discusses the hardware and software components of the testbed, as well as its potential applications for research and education. This work is ongoing and future plans for the testbed's expansion are outlined.
column3: Up and Away: A Cheap UAV Cyber-Physical Testbed (Work in Progress)

column1: This paper discusses the use of a modified multi-model predictive control algorithm for the optimization of a fluid catalytic cracking unit. The proposed algorithm utilizes model-based predictive control strategies to enhance the performance of the unit and is able to effectively handle multiple models, enabling the system to adapt to varying operating conditions. The study demonstrates the effectiveness of this approach in controlling the key process variables, including reactor temperature, catalyst circulation rate, and product yields. The results show that the modified multi-model predictive control algorithm offers improved performance compared to traditional model-based control strategies and can be applied to other industrial processes beyond the fluid catalytic cracking unit.
column3: Application of Modified Multi Model Predictive Control Algorithm to  Fluid Catalytic Cracking Unit

column1: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of Load Frequency Control (LFC) techniques for both single area and multi-area distributed power systems. The major focus is on the design and application of proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controllers for LFC in order to ensure stable and reliable power supply in these systems. Various scenarios, including system disturbances and different control strategies, are examined to evaluate the performance of the proposed approach. Simulation results show that the PID controller based LFC technique is effective in regulating the frequency and load power in both single area and multi-area distributed power systems.
column3: Load Frequency Control For Distributed Grid Power System Single Area &  Multi-area System

column1: This paper proposes a novel reduction scheme for Gaussian sum filters, which significantly improves the computational efficiency of Gaussian mixture models. The proposed method achieves this by reducing the number of terms in the summation involved in evaluating the Gaussian sum filter, without sacrificing accuracy. Specifically, the reduction scheme uses a clustering approach to group similar Gaussian components in the mixture, resulting in a much smaller set of terms that need to be evaluated. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme on various benchmark datasets, highlighting its potential for improving the efficiency of practical applications of Gaussian mixture models.
column3: A New Reduction Scheme for Gaussian Sum Filters

column1: This paper presents a novel approach to the problem of containment control for multi-agent systems in the presence of measurement noises. Specifically, we propose a distributed control algorithm that allows a group of agents to reach consensus on a desired trajectory while simultaneously minimizing the effect of measurement errors. The approach builds upon a combination of matrix algebra and graph theory to design a robust controller that accounts for uncertainties in the measurement process. The theoretical analysis of the controller is supported by numerical simulations, which demonstrate the effectiveness and the resilience of the proposed approach. The results of this study shed light on the potential of distributed control strategies for handling noise and disturbances in multi-agent systems.
column3: Containment control of multi-agent systems with measurement noises
