The paper explores several approaches to parameter adaptation, including data-driven methods and analytical methods, with a focus on their effectiveness and computational efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate the advantages of parameter adaptation in improving the performance of RF power amplifier behavioral models in practical applications. Overall, this paper highlights the importance of parameter adaptation in improving the accuracy and effectiveness of RF power amplifier modeling.
column3: Investigation of Parameter Adaptation in RF Power Amplifier Behavioral  Models

column1: The paper titled Maximum Entropy Property of Discrete-time Stable Spline Kernel presents an investigation into the maximum entropy property of the discrete-time stable spline kernel. The study explores the mathematical foundation of the stable spline kernel and applies rigorous analytical methods to establish its maximum entropy characteristics. The paper also examines the implications of these findings in various signal processing applications, providing insight into the suitability of the stable spline kernel for different applications. The paper contributes to the existing knowledge on stable spline kernels, shedding light on a largely unexplored area of research.
column3: Maximum Entropy Property of Discrete-time Stable Spline Kernel

column1: This paper investigates the stability conditions of Kalman filtering over Gilbert-Elliott channels. The Gilbert-Elliott model is widely used for modeling communication channels in which the channel state alternates between two states: good and bad. The stability of the filter is essential for reliable and accurate estimation of the channel state. In this paper, we derive the stability conditions and analyze the critical curve of the filter. The critical curve determines the boundary between stable and unstable regions of the system. Our results contribute to the understanding of the performance of Kalman filtering over Gilbert-Elliott channels, which has important applications in wireless communication and signal processing.
column3: Kalman Filtering over Gilbert-Elliott Channels: Stability Conditions and  the Critical Curve

column1: This paper investigates the application of the Kullback-Leibler divergence in the context of interacting multiple model estimation with random matrices. The study aims to provide a novel framework for analyzing the performance of estimation algorithms in complex, dynamic systems. Using simulations and real-world examples, the article demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed approach for tracking the behavior of multiple sub-models and improving overall estimation accuracy. The findings suggest that implementing the Kullback-Leibler divergence in interacting multiple model estimation can lead to notable advancements in the field of system identification and control.
column3: Kullback-Leibler divergence for interacting multiple model estimation  with random matrices

column1: This paper presents a comprehensive overview of state of charge (SOC) evolution equations for flywheels. Flywheels, as an energy storage technology, have been receiving increasing attention due to their fast response time and long lifespan. However, accurately modeling their SOC is critical for efficient use in real-world applications. This paper analyzes the current state of knowledge on various factors affecting SOC evolution, including flywheel material properties, rotational speed, and energy throughput. Furthermore, insights are drawn from experimental and theoretical studies to derive effective SOC evolution equations for flywheels. Our findings suggest that these equations can improve the accuracy of flywheel energy management systems, enabling optimized utilization of this promising technology.
column3: State of Charge Evolution Equations for Flywheels

column1: This paper explores the modeling of populations of thermostatic loads with switching rate actuation. The use of switching rate actuation has gained popularity as it allows for more flexibility in controlling power demand. The paper describes a mathematical model that takes into account the switching behavior of appliances in a population and its impact on energy demand. Simulation results illustrate the effectiveness of the model in predicting power demand at different times of the day, with implications for load management and energy conservation strategies.
column3: Modeling Populations of Thermostatic Loads with Switching Rate Actuation

column1: This paper explores the deployment of multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for optimal crop-dusting of crops infested with anomalous diffusion pests. The aim is to minimize the spread of the infestation across the entire crop field while limiting the use of pesticides. The study considers the dynamics of the infestation spread and develops an optimal control approach that combines the movements of the multiple UAVs to spray the crops at optimal locations and times. The proposed approach takes into account the infestation density, the crop size, and the wind direction to optimize the efficacy of the crop-dusting measures. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in controlling the infestation spread and reducing the use of pesticides. The multi-UAV-based approach presents a promising solution for the efficient and environmentally friendly management of crop pests.
column3: Multi-UAV-based Optimal Crop-dusting of Anomalously Diffusing  Infestation of Crops

column1: This paper presents a comprehensive comparison study of semi-active suspension control using modern methodology. The study compares the performance of three different semi-active control strategies using simulations and experimental testing. The first approach is a classic skyhook control, the second is a modern Model Predictive Control (MPC) and the third is the recently developed Discrete Sliding Mode Control (DSMC). The three control strategies are analyzed and compared in terms of ride comfort, road handling performance, and stability control. The results demonstrate that the DSMC controller provides the best overall suspension performance compared to the other two controllers. The study provides a valuable insight on the latest developments in semi-active suspension control and highlights the potential of DSMC for future applications.
column3: Semi-active Suspension Control using Modern Methodology: Comprehensive  Comparison Study

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach for simultaneous velocity and position estimation in multi-agent systems using distance-only measurements. By integrating the sensor measurements and dynamic models, an extended Kalman filter is developed to estimate the relative positions and velocities of the agents. The proposed method is then applied to a multi-agent control problem, where a leader agent navigates a group of followers to a desired formation. Simulation results demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed approach, showing accurate estimation and successful control in a multi-agent system.
column3: Simultaneous Velocity and Position Estimation via Distance-only  Measurements with Application to Multi-Agent System Control

column1: This paper presents a theoretical analysis of the Kaczmarz algorithm for solving linear systems. Specifically, we explore the convergence properties of the algorithm and prove that it exhibits exponential convergence for certain classes of matrices. Our analysis highlights the importance of the spectrum of the matrix in determining the rate of convergence, and we provide numerical experiments to support our findings. Ultimately, this work contributes to a deeper understanding of the Kaczmarz algorithm and its potential applications in scientific computing and related fields.
column3: On the exponential convergence of the Kaczmarz algorithm

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for optimizing the direct weight of recursive structures. The proposed method utilizes a derivation technique to uncover important properties of the recursive structure and exploit them to efficiently adjust the direct weight. By combining this technique with optimization algorithms, significant improvements in accuracy and speed are achieved. Results from experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in a variety of applications, including signal processing and machine learning. The proposed method offers a valuable contribution to the field of recursive direct weight optimization and holds promise for future research endeavors.
column3: A new structure exploiting derivation of recursive direct weight  optimization

column1: This paper investigates the phenomenon of cycle slipping in nonlinear circuits under the influence of periodic nonlinearities and time delays. The study explores the impact of these factors on the stability and performance of nonlinear electronic circuits. Analytical and numerical approaches are employed to evaluate the effects of periodicity and time delay on the occurrence of cycle slips. The paper presents several models for predicting cycle slipping behavior in nonlinear circuits and proposes practical solutions for mitigating this phenomenon. The results of this study have implications for the design and optimization of nonlinear circuits in a diverse range of applications, including communication systems, power electronics, and control systems.
column3: Cycle slipping in nonlinear circuits under periodic nonlinearities and  time delays

column1: This paper presents a study on the estimation of transient processes for singularly perturbed synchronization systems with distributed parameters. The proposed approach utilizes advanced mathematical tools to develop a framework based on robust stabilization theory, which offers effective solutions for estimating transient behavior in these systems. The paper highlights the key features of the proposed framework and demonstrates its effectiveness through a series of numerical experiments. The results support the applicability of the proposed methodology for estimating transient processes in singularly perturbed synchronization systems with distributed parameters. Overall, the paper offers valuable insights into the design and implementation of reliable and robust estimation frameworks for complex systems.
column3: Estimation of transient process for singularly perturbed synchronization  system with distributed parameters

column1: This paper presents a probabilistic model for transmission line temperatures under varying power flows. The proposed method incorporates a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm to simulate the temperature distribution of the transmission lines. The model takes into account both steady-state and transient conditions of power flow. The results of the simulation show that the proposed method is effective in accurately predicting transmission line temperatures and can aid in improving the efficiency and reliability of power systems.
column3: Probabilistic Modeling and Simulation of Transmission Line Temperatures  under Fluctuating Power Flows

column1: This paper presents a method for the optimal reduction of multivariate Dirac mixture densities. The proposed approach aims to minimize the distance between the original density and the reduced density while ensuring that the reduced density accurately represents the original density. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this method through experimental results on synthetic and real-world datasets. The proposed method has the potential to improve the performance of various applications, including machine learning and computer vision.
column3: Optimal Reduction of Multivariate Dirac Mixture Densities

column1: This paper focuses on the optimization of a hybrid PV/wind power system for remote telecom stations. Renewable energy systems have emerged as a viable solution for powering off-grid telecom stations. A hybrid PV/wind power system can provide an efficient and cost-effective solution for meeting the energy demands of remote telecom stations. The objective of this paper is to optimize the hybrid PV/wind system by maximizing the utilization of renewable energy sources and minimizing the use of backup generators. The study presents the sizing of the hybrid system components and proposes a control strategy for the effective operation of the system. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed system in providing reliable and sustainable energy for remote telecom stations while reducing fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.
column3: Optimization of Hybrid PV/Wind Power System for Remote Telecom Station

column1: This paper presents a submodular optimization framework for achieving global practical node and edge synchronization in Kuramoto networks. The proposed approach aims to strategically select the minimum set of nodes and edges to synchronize, which enables the entire network to reach a synchronized state. The framework is shown to be effective in achieving synchronization in randomly generated networks as well as real-world power grid networks. The results demonstrate the ability of the proposed method to surpass existing synchronization methods in terms of synchronization speed and energy efficiency. Overall, this paper offers valuable insights into the development of practical synchronization strategies for complex networks.
column3: Global Practical Node and Edge Synchronization in Kuramoto Networks: A  Submodular Optimization Framework

column1: This paper proposes a threshold-based monitoring approach for detecting and characterizing cascading outages in power systems. The proposed approach uses phasor measurement unit (PMU) measurements of area angle to estimate the magnitude and direction of power system oscillations, which are indicative of an impending cascading outage. By setting appropriate threshold values and analyzing the PMU data in real-time, the proposed approach can quickly detect and track the evolution of cascading outages. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated using simulation studies of a power system under different scenarios of cascading outages. The results show that the proposed approach can accurately identify and localize cascading outages and provide useful information for system operators to take appropriate actions to prevent or mitigate cascading outages.
column3: Threshold-based monitoring of cascading outages with PMU measurements of  area angle

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach for output feedback stabilization of switched linear systems with limited information. The system under consideration is assumed to have multiple modes, each with a distinct linear model. The limited information refers to the fact that only the output measurements are available for control design. The proposed method employs a switching signal to combine multiple linear observers and a controller to stabilize the system. The stability analysis of the closed-loop system is presented using the Lyapunov approach. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through numerical simulations.
column3: Output Feedback Stabilization of Switched Linear Systems with Limited  Information

column1: This paper presents a method for designing parameter spaces of repetitive controllers to ensure robust performance in uncertain systems. The proposed approach takes into account the uncertain elements of the system and introduces a set of constraints to obtain a parameter space that guarantees robust stability and performance. The resulting design is verified through simulations, demonstrating its effectiveness in satisfying the specified performance requirements. Overall, the approach presented in this paper provides a valuable contribution to the field of control system design, particularly for systems subject to uncertain disturbances.
column3: Parameter Space Design of Repetitive Controllers for Satisfying a Robust  Performance Requirement

column1: This paper explores the use of opportunistic routing in the Vehicular Energy Network (VEN). The VEN is a new paradigm that uses electric vehicles (EVs) as mobile energy storage devices, which can provide energy to other nodes in the network. Opportunistic routing can take advantage of the mobility of EVs and the wireless communication links between them to increase energy delivery efficiency, thus reducing the overall energy consumption in the network. In this paper, we propose a novel opportunistic routing algorithm for the VEN and evaluate its performance with simulation experiments. Results show that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing routing protocols in terms of energy efficiency and delivery rate, thus contributing to the development of sustainable and efficient VENs.
column3: Opportunistic Routing for the Vehicular Energy Network

column1: This paper presents a novel approach to hypothesis testing and the structure of corresponding confidence intervals using perturbed datasets. Specifically, we introduce a new framework for constructing perturbed datasets that more accurately reflect the underlying distribution, resulting in improved statistical inference. We provide theoretical justification for our approach and demonstrate its effectiveness through simulation studies and real data applications. Our results suggest that the use of perturbed datasets can lead to more accurate hypothesis testing and more informative confidence intervals. Overall, this paper contributes to the ongoing effort to improve statistical methodology and enhance the reliability of research findings.
column3: Perturbed Datasets Methods for Hypothesis Testing and Structure of  Corresponding Confidence Sets

column1: This paper investigates the mean-square performance of the constrained least mean squares (LMS) algorithm. The authors explore the effect of the constraints on the convergence rate and the steady-state performance of the algorithm. The analysis is carried out using matrix algebra and statistical techniques, and the results are derived under assumptions of random input and zero-mean error. Simulation results are also provided to illustrate the theoretical findings. The findings suggest that appropriate constraints can improve the performance of the constrained LMS algorithm compared to the unconstrained version, particularly in the presence of noise and/or outliers. Overall, this study contributes to a better understanding of the key factors that affect the performance of the constrained LMS algorithm in practical applications.
column3: On the Mean-Square Performance of the Constrained LMS Algorithm

column1: This paper presents a cooperative change detection algorithm for online power quality monitoring in smart grid. The proposed algorithm aims to detect changes in the power quality parameters as early as possible, and trigger proactive actions to improve power quality. The proposed algorithm employs a cooperative approach that combines the local detection results from multiple monitoring nodes, and integrates them using a weight-based fusion method. The simulation experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in terms of both the detection accuracy and the communication overhead. The proposed algorithm is anticipated to be a valuable contribution to the power quality monitoring in smart grid.
column3: Cooperative Change Detection for Online Power Quality Monitoring

column1: This paper presents a novel approach to optimal control problems within the framework of Path Integral Control (PIC). Specifically, the paper utilizes Bayesian Nonparametrics to estimate the underlying dynamics of the system, allowing for a model-based approach to PIC. The proposed approach is evaluated on a set of simulated systems, showcasing its superior performance compared to traditional non-Bayesian approaches. Overall, this paper highlights the effectiveness of Bayesian Nonparametrics in addressing control problems, and the potential for model-based PIC algorithms to improve system performance.
column3: Model-based Path Integral Stochastic Control: A Bayesian Nonparametric  Approach

column1: This paper proposes a new kernel-based approach for identifying Hammerstein systems, which are characterized by a static nonlinear block followed by a linear dynamic block. The proposed approach employs a nonlinear reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS) to obtain a compact representation of the input-output map of the system. The linear dynamic block is then identified using standard linear system identification techniques. The proposed method is compared with existing methods on simulated and experimental data, and superior performance is demonstrated in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.
column3: A kernel-based approach to Hammerstein system identification

column1: This paper explores the design and implementation of an in-vivo network of sensors and actuators for real-time monitoring and control of biological systems. The proposed system utilizes a combination of implanted sensors and actuators to gather and manipulate data in real-time. The paper discusses the various components of the system, the configuration of the network, and the methods of data analysis. Furthermore, potential applications of the in-vivo network of sensors and actuators are also discussed, including the ability to monitor healthy physiological functions, monitor disease progression, and enable targeted drug delivery. Overall, this innovative approach to in-vivo monitoring and control provides promising opportunities for advancements in the field of biotechnology.
column3: In-vivo Network of Sensors and Actuators

column1: This paper addresses the problem of achieving consensus in multi-agent systems where agents communicate with each other through state-dependent information transmission. We propose a decentralized consensus algorithm that allows agents to reach agreement on a common target state by exchanging information only with neighboring agents whose states satisfy certain conditions. We analyze the convergence properties of the algorithm and show that it can achieve consensus in various scenarios, including asymmetrical communication topologies and the presence of external disturbances. Our simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed algorithm in achieving consensus in a distributed and dynamic system.
column3: Consensus of Multi-agent Systems Under State-dependent Information  Transmission

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for Approximate Bayesian Smoothing (ABS) with unknown process and measurement noise covariances. The proposed method involves using an Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm to estimate the unknown noise covariances. This approach is tested on a variety of synthetic and real-world datasets, and compared to other popular smoothing algorithms. Results demonstrate that the ABS with unknown noise covariances outperforms other methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. This paper provides new insights and practical implications for the ABS method and its applications to real-world problems.
column3: Approximate Bayesian Smoothing with Unknown Process and Measurement  Noise Covariances

column1: This paper proposes a novel nonlinear tracking algorithm that utilizes range-rate measurements and an unbiased measurement conversion approach. The algorithm ensures accurate tracking of a moving target in a non-linear system, even in the presence of measurement errors and uncertainties. The proposed method is compared to existing linear and nonlinear algorithms, demonstrating superior performance in terms of root mean square error and tracking precision. The proposed algorithm has potential applications in numerous fields, including robotics, aerospace, and autonomous systems.
column3: A nonlinear tracking algorithm with range-rate measurements based on  unbiased measurement conversion

column1: This paper proposes a decentralized formation control approach based on a quadratic Lyapunov function. The method presented allows a group of autonomous agents to converge to and maintain a desired formation while minimizing inter-agent distance and avoiding collisions. The approach is decentralized, meaning that agents only require local information and interact with their immediate neighbors to achieve the desired formation. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through simulation results, showing robustness to disturbances and scalability to large groups of agents.
column3: Decentralized Formation Control with A Quadratic Lyapunov Function

column1: This paper explores the controllability of formations over time-varying graphs. The concept of formation control has been widely studied in multi-agent systems, but previous works have mostly focused on static graphs. This paper considers time-varying graphs, which are more applicable to real-world scenarios, and investigates the controllability of formations under such circumstances. The authors propose a novel control strategy that guarantees the formation controllability over time-varying graphs, proving its effectiveness and robustness through theoretical analysis and numerical simulations. The results provide valuable insights for the design and optimization of formation control systems in dynamic environments.
column3: Controllability of Formations over Time-varying Graphs

column1: This paper investigates the collective behavior of swarms under the influence of fading attractions. The study considers an environment in which the attractive forces between swarm members weaken over time, leading to changes in the aggregation patterns of the swarm. The research explores the emergence of new patterns in these dynamic systems and analyzes the impact of different parameters on the swarm behavior. The study also proposes a novel approach based on machine learning techniques to predict the future behavior of swarms under changing attractions. The findings of this research provide insights into the behavior of complex systems and have implications for the design of multi-agent systems in various fields.
column3: Swarm Aggregation under Fading Attractions

column1: This paper explores network synchronization with convexity as a novel approach to achieving coordinated behavior among networked agents. We introduce a convex optimization framework for designing synchronization protocols and demonstrate its effectiveness in achieving synchronization in multi-agent systems. Our methodology also allows for agent dynamics and communication topologies to be incorporated into the optimization problem. Simulation results show that the proposed approach outperforms existing synchronization methods in terms of convergence speed and stability. Overall, our study highlights the potential of convex optimization in addressing synchronization challenges in complex networks.
column3: Network Synchronization with Convexity

column1: This paper aims to address the challenge of accurate time synchronization in mobile wireless sensor networks operating in noisy environments. In this paper, a novel approach based on distributed time synchronization from noisy difference measurements is proposed. The proposed approach is capable of achieving high synchronization accuracy even in the presence of significant noise and mobility. The performance of the proposed approach is evaluated through extensive simulations, which demonstrate its superiority over existing time synchronization methods. The results of this study have important implications for the design and operation of mobile wireless sensor networks in real-world environments.
column3: Accurate Distributed Time Synchronization in Mobile Wireless Sensor  Networks from Noisy Difference Measurements

column1: This paper presents an analysis of asymptotic stability for stochastic linear time-varying (LTV) systems. We demonstrate that such systems can be stabilized by designing appropriate output feedback control laws. The analysis is applied to distributed dynamic fusion, a problem in which multiple agents must coordinate their actions to estimate a common system state. By leveraging the stability result and optimizing the feedback control laws, we show that the distributed dynamic fusion problem can be effectively solved. Our theoretical results are supported by numerical simulations.
column3: Asymptotic stability of stochastic LTV systems with applications to  distributed dynamic fusion

column1: This paper proposes novel qualitatively accurate spectral schemes for advection and transport, which serve as an effective numerical tool for simulating fluid dynamics and transport phenomena. The schemes use modified spectral representations that capture relevant physical phenomena even in the presence of discontinuities and shocks, preserving the positivity and stability of the solution. The numerical methods are tested on a range of standard problems, demonstrating superior performance compared to existing schemes, with potential applications in the fields of weather forecasting, climate modeling, and fluid mechanics.
column3: Qualitatively accurate spectral schemes for advection and transport

column1: This study investigates the impact of wind energy generation on the stability of power systems. Specifically, the research focuses on how the integration of wind energy sources affects the frequency stability and electromechanical oscillations of the system. The study utilizes simulation tools to analyze different scenarios of wind power integration and their impact on the stability of the power grid. The results of the study underscore the importance of addressing the frequency control and electromechanical issues related to wind energy integration, in order to ensure the stability and reliability of power systems.
column3: A Study on the Impact of Wind Generation on the Stability of  Electromechanical Oscillations

column1: This paper presents a constructive proof of the phase-type characterization theorem, a fundamental result in stochastic processes. The theorem asserts that a probability distribution is phase-type if and only if its Laplace transform has a rational form. We present a new proof of this theorem that provides an explicit construction of the corresponding phase-type distribution. This constructive approach has several advantages over previous proofs, including a simpler and more intuitive interpretation of the result, as well as potential applications in simulation and modeling. We also present several examples and applications of the phase-type characterization theorem to demonstrate its usefulness in practice.
column3: A constructive proof of the phase-type characterization theorem

column1: This paper proposes an optimal two-tier forecasting power generation model in smart grids. The model aims to improve the accuracy of power generation forecasting and enhance the reliability and efficiency of smart grids. Based on the historical data of power generation and meteorological variables, the model employs a hybrid approach that combines artificial neural network and autoregressive integrated moving average models. Furthermore, an optimization algorithm is developed to determine the optimal number of layers and nodes for artificial neural network. Experimental results show that the proposed model outperforms traditional forecasting methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency, highlighting its potential as a promising approach for power generation forecasting in smart grids.
column3: Optimal Two-Tier Forecasting Power Generation Model in Smart Grids

column1: This paper explores the application of quantized consensus using the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM). Specifically, it investigates the performance of both probabilistic and deterministic quantizers in achieving consensus among a group of distributed agents. The study evaluates the convergence rate and accuracy of the quantized consensus algorithms in different scenarios, including cases with noisy communication channels and a varying number of agents. The results demonstrate the advantages and limitations of both types of quantizers and provide insights for selecting the most suitable method for different applications.
column3: Quantized Consensus by the ADMM: Probabilistic versus Deterministic  Quantizers

column1: This paper presents a method for achieving consensus in multi-agent systems with linear objective maps. Consensus is defined as the state in which all agents reach the same decision or value. We introduce a framework based on distributed optimization that enables agents to converge to this state while minimizing a linear objective function. The proposed method is scalable to networks with large numbers of agents and can handle nonlinear constraints. Our simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the approach in achieving consensus in a variety of scenarios.
column3: Consensus with Linear Objective Maps

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for sensor control in multi-object tracking using a labeled multi-Bernoulli filter. The proposed method utilizes the information from multiple sensors to accurately track and estimate the locations of multiple objects in a complex dynamic environment. The labeled multi-Bernoulli filter is employed for object segmentation and classification, while sensor control is achieved through a maximum mutual information criterion. The proposed approach was evaluated using simulated data and real-world data from multiple sensors. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique in achieving improved multi-object tracking accuracy and robustness, particularly in complex and cluttered environments.
column3: Sensor Control for Multi-Object Tracking Using Labeled Multi-Bernoulli  Filter

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach for achieving unique localizability in cooperative localization of wireless sensor networks (WSNs). The approach is based on the use of graph invariants, specifically the rigidity index and redundancy index, to determine the number of measurements needed for unique localization. The paper presents a rigorous mathematical analysis of the proposed approach and demonstrates its effectiveness through simulations. The results show that the proposed approach outperforms existing methods and can significantly improve the localization accuracy of WSNs.
column3: Graph invariants for unique localizability in cooperative localization  of wireless sensor networks: rigidity index and redundancy index

column1: This paper explores the concept of multiuser charging control in wireless power transfer via magnetic resonant coupling. The objective is to achieve efficient and fair distribution of power among multiple users. The study proposes a novel approach where the charging process is regulated based on the real-time monitoring of power-delivery efficiency and user requirements. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique in achieving improved charging control, energy efficiency, and user satisfaction.
column3: Multiuser Charging Control in Wireless Power Transfer via Magnetic  Resonant Coupling

column1: This paper explores a novel approach to modeling consensus dynamics in multi-agent systems through the integration of an inertial component into the Hegselmann-Krause model. By introducing a factor of inertia, the resulting Inertial Hegselmann-Krause system can better capture the behaviors of real-world systems where agents have a tendency to resist abrupt changes in their opinions or beliefs. Through analysis and simulations, we demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach in achieving consensus while maintaining a balance between individual deviations and global coherence. The results of this study have practical implications for the design and implementation of distributed decision-making systems in a variety of domains, such as social networks or autonomous vehicles.
column3: Inertial Hegselmann-Krause Systems

column1: This paper presents a state estimation and malicious attack game for multi-sensor dynamic systems. The proposed game-theoretic approach considers the interaction between an attacker and the estimator, taking into account the estimation errors and the costs associated with potential attacks. The analysis of the proposed approach is carried out through simulations demonstrating its effectiveness in mitigating the effects of malicious attacks on the system's state estimation performance. The results of this study have relevant implications for the design and development of more secure and reliable multi-sensor dynamic systems.
column3: A State Estimation and Malicious Attack Game in Multi-Sensor Dynamic  Systems

column1: This paper examines the development of effective customer engagement plans in the context of residential smart grids with the aim of reducing peak load demand. The focus is on identifying the key drivers of customer engagement and exploring effective strategies for engaging customers in energy reduction behaviors during peak periods. The study draws on empirical evidence from existing literature and case studies to uncover best practices for customer engagement-based demand response in smart grids. The paper concludes by outlining practical recommendations to support the implementation of effective customer engagement plans in peak load reduction initiatives, highlighting the importance of communication, education, and incentives in promoting sustainable energy practices.
column3: Customer Engagement Plans for Peak Load Reduction in Residential Smart  Grids

column1: This paper presents a comparison study of different nonlinear attitude filtering techniques. Attitude estimation is crucial for various applications like spacecraft, planes, and drones. The study compares and evaluates different nonlinear filters like Unscented Kalman Filter, Extended Kalman Filter, and Particle Filter. We analyze their performance based on several criteria such as accuracy, efficiency, and robustness. The comparison results show that the Particle Filter outperforms the other two filters in terms of accuracy and robustness but with higher computational complexity. The paper provides insights into which nonlinear attitude filtering technique to choose for specific applications.
column3: Nonlinear Attitude Filtering: A Comparison Study

column1: This paper proposes a methodology for guaranteed consensus performance in leader-follower tracking control for interconnected systems with linear dynamic uncertain coupling. The proposed approach utilizes a Lyapunov-based controller framework combined with a control allocation algorithm. The Lyapunov-based controller ensures stability and convergence to the leader trajectory, while the control allocation algorithm optimally distributes the control effort among the followers to minimize tracking error. The proposed methodology is validated through simulation results on different interconnected systems with various levels of uncertainty. The results show improved tracking performance compared to existing methods, while maintaining guaranteed consensus performance. The proposed approach has potential applications in multi-agent systems, unmanned aerial vehicles, and industrial control systems.
column3: Leader-follower Tracking Control with Guaranteed Consensus Performance  for Interconnected Systems with Linear Dynamic Uncertain Coupling

column1: This paper introduces the concept of radial fuzzy systems, a novel approach to designing fuzzy systems based on radial basis functions. The paper provides an overview of fuzzy systems, radial basis functions, and their respective applications. It then delves into the construction of radial fuzzy systems, including the selection of input variables, membership functions, and fuzzy rules. The paper also discusses the performance of radial fuzzy systems compared to traditional fuzzy systems and other machine learning algorithms. This study highlights the benefits of radial fuzzy systems, such as their ability to handle non-linear and high-dimensional problems, their efficiency in training, and their interpretability. Overall, this paper provides a comprehensive exploration of radial fuzzy systems and their potential applications in various fields.
column3: Radial Fuzzy Systems

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach to probabilistic certification of combined cancer therapies using strongly uncertain models. The use of combined therapies has become more common in cancer treatment, but evaluating their effectiveness can be challenging due to uncertainty in biological and clinical factors. The proposed approach considers the uncertainty of various treatment choices and probabilistically certifies that the combined therapy is effective. The results of this study can provide valuable insights for oncologists and healthcare professionals to make informed decisions on the most effective cancer treatment options.
column3: On Probabilistic Certification of Combined Cancer Therapies Using  Strongly Uncertain Models

column1: The paper titled 'Recharging Probably Keeps Batteries Alive' presents a study that aimed to investigate the effects of regular recharging on the lifetime of batteries. The study evaluated the lifespan of batteries that were regularly recharged and those that were only recharged when they were completely depleted. The results indicate that batteries that were regularly recharged showed a longer lifespan compared to those that were regularly allowed to completely discharge. Additionally, the study also found that the type of charger used can also influence the lifetime of batteries. This paper provides useful insights for individuals and organizations seeking to extend the lifespan of their batteries, which can potentially reduce their carbon footprint and also result in financial savings.
column3: Recharging Probably Keeps Batteries Alive

column1: This paper discusses the autonomous vehicle public transportation system and its scheduling and admission control. The autonomous vehicle technology has revolutionized public transportation, making it more reliable, efficient, and cost-effective. The scheduling and admission control are crucial components of this system, as they ensure smooth operation and optimal utilization of resources. This paper presents a novel approach to scheduling and admission control, incorporating machine learning algorithms and traffic prediction models. The proposed approach provides a flexible and adaptive system that can adjust to changing traffic conditions and demands. The results of the simulation show that the proposed approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of passenger satisfaction, waiting time, and resource utilization. The findings of this study suggest that the proposed system can serve as a model for future autonomous vehicle public transportation systems.
column3: Autonomous Vehicle Public Transportation System: Scheduling and  Admission Control

column1: This paper introduces a novel data-driven approach for robust receding horizon fault estimation in dynamic systems. The presented framework utilizes historical system data to iteratively update a fault estimator in real-time, effectively accounting for model uncertainties and disturbances. The proposed methodology is shown to yield accurate and efficient fault detection and estimation results, further validated through extensive simulation studies and experimental evaluations. Overall, this new approach holds great promise for enhancing the reliability and performance of fault estimation techniques in diverse engineering applications.
column3: Data-Driven Robust Receding Horizon Fault Estimation

column1: This paper presents a new approach to Anytime Model Predictive Control using convex feasibility techniques. We propose a method for solving the optimization problem that underlies MPC in a way that enables the controller to make fast and efficient decisions in real-time. The algorithm presented involves repeated applications of a convex feasibility solver that converges to a feasible solution of the optimization problem. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach through simulations and comparisons to traditional optimization methods commonly used in MPC. The results indicate that this approach provides a promising framework for implementing MPC in various applications.
column3: A Convex Feasibility Approach to Anytime Model Predictive Control

column1: This paper presents a novel approach to feedback interconnected multi-agent systems by utilizing decentralized abstractions. The proposed framework enables agents to improve their individual performance by taking into account the feedback received from their neighboring agents in a distributed fashion. The theoretical analysis and simulations demonstrate the benefits of the proposed framework in enhancing coordination and achieving system-level objectives. This work contributes towards the development of scalable, decentralized control strategies for complex multi-agent systems.
column3: Decentralized Abstractions for Feedback Interconnected Multi-Agent  Systems

column1: The paper titled 'Improved Stability Analysis of Nonlinear Networked Control Systems over Multiple Communication Links' presents a novel approach for improving the stability analysis of nonlinear networked control systems (NCSs) over multiple communication links. The proposed approach integrates different techniques such as decentralized control and Lyapunov stability theory to develop a more robust and efficient system. The paper further elaborates on the theoretical analyses and simulations performed to validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. The results obtained demonstrate the improved stability and performance achieved by the developed approach, making it a promising tool for the design of advanced NCSs.
column3: Improved Stability Analysis of Nonlinear Networked Control Systems over  Multiple Communication Links

column1: The performance of control systems is impacted by time delay in the control loop, causing undesirable effects such as slower response time and oscillations. This paper proposes a modification of time delay in control systems to improve their performance. Using simulation experiments, we demonstrate that modifying the time delay can lead to significant improvements in response time and stability, which can be applied to real-world control systems in various industries. Our findings suggest that control system designers and operators should consider modifying time delay as a viable option to enhance control system performance.
column3: Improvement of Control System Performance by Modification of Time Delay

column1: This research paper presents an interoperable implementation of smart cities with the help of plug and play based device management. The proposed approach aims to provide seamless integration and management of a wide range of smart devices with diverse protocols, resulting in a future-proof and flexible smart city infrastructure. Additionally, the paper explores the benefits of the proposed approach, such as reduced implementation costs, easy scalability, and improved device management efficiency, leading to an overall improvement in the citizen's quality of life. The study concluded that the plug and play-based device management approach significantly contributes to the interoperability and successful implementation of smart cities, making it a promising solution for future smart city infrastructures.
column3: An Interoperable Realization of Smart Cities with Plug and Play based  Device Management

column1: This paper presents a data-driven approach for estimating the benefits of electric vehicle smart charging at non-residential locations. The study utilizes historical charging data collected from charging stations across several locations and analyzes the potential for reduced costs, increased grid stability, and decreased greenhouse gas emissions associated with smart charging. The findings suggest that implementing smart charging strategies can lead to significant benefits for both the electric vehicle drivers and the grid operators. This research provides important insights for policymakers and stakeholders involved in the planning and deployment of smart charging infrastructure.
column3: Estimating the Benefits of Electric Vehicle Smart Charging at  Non-Residential Locations: A Data-Driven Approach

column1: This paper compares the performance of gradient-based Lp-LMS algorithms for sparse system identification. The focus is on identifying sparse signals or systems using a variety of Lp-norms with the goal of improving performance and robustness of the identification process. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in accurately identifying sparse systems while also providing insight into the trade-offs between performance and computational complexity. Overall, this paper presents a valuable contribution to the field of sparse system identification by introducing and evaluating a range of Lp-norm based methods.
column3: Gradient Compared Lp-LMS Algorithms for Sparse System Identification

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach to accelerate consensus building in networked systems by combining spectral clustering and polynomial filters. The method helps in identifying the influential nodes and effectively filters out the contributions of low-impact nodes to enhance convergence speed. The proposed technique was evaluated on several benchmarks and real-world datasets, demonstrating significant improvement in convergence speed and accuracy compared to other consensus building techniques. The results suggest that spectral clustering and polynomial filters can be an effective tool for accelerating consensus in various networked systems.
column3: Accelerating Consensus by Spectral Clustering and Polynomial Filters

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach for sparse system identification using a p norm constraint leaky LMS algorithm. The algorithm aims to identify systems with a small number of non-zero coefficients by regularizing the LMS update using a p-norm constraint. Simulation results show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of sparsity and identification accuracy, making it a promising tool for sparse system identification.
column3: p Norm Constraint Leaky LMS Algorithm for Sparse System Identification

column1: This paper proposes a novel p-norm-like constraint leaky LMS (PLL-LMS) algorithm for identifying sparse systems. The proposed algorithm incorporates both sparsity and a constraint to the p-norm of the weight vector into the standard LMS algorithm. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm was evaluated through extensive simulations, and the results show that the PLL-LMS algorithm is able to identify sparse systems more accurately and efficiently than standard LMS algorithms. These findings have important implications for applications in signal processing, pattern recognition, and related fields.
column3: p-norm-like Constraint Leaky LMS Algorithm for Sparse System  Identification

column1: The development of power system circuit models is a fundamental element in the design, simulation, and analysis of power systems. The use of different software tools for system modeling and simulation presents several challenges, particularly with transferring data between different software packages. In this paper, we present a unified platform that enables power system circuit model data transfer among different software. The proposed platform - named PSCMT - provides a common standard for power system circuit modeling that allows seamless transition between different software. This platform operates by transforming the circuit model data from one software package to another using data transfer conversion techniques. We demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our platform by performing a case study that involves data transfer between two widely used power system simulation software packages: MATLAB Simulink and PSCAD. Our results show that PSCMT provides an efficient and reliable solution for data transfer, enabling power system designers and researchers to easily and efficiently interface circuit models between different software tools.
column3: A Unified Platform Enabling Power System Circuit Model Data Transfer  Among Different Software

column1: This paper presents a study on Model Predictive Control (MPC) under Timing Constraints induced by Controller Area Networks (CAN) in real-time control systems. The objective is to design a novel MPC algorithm that considers the communication delays in CAN and optimizes the control performance while satisfying the timing constraints. First, the communication time delays between the controller and actuator are modeled and incorporated into the MPC formulation. Then, an optimization problem is formulated to minimize the control error subject to the timing constraints. Simulation results show that the proposed MPC algorithm effectively reduces the control error while meeting real-time timing requirements induced by CAN.
column3: Model Predictive Control under Timing Constraints induced by Controller  Area Networks

column1: This paper presents a robust Proportional-Integral (PI) passivity-based control strategy for nonlinear systems. The approach is demonstrated on Port-Hamiltonian systems with temperature regulation as an application. The proposed method ensures passivity of the closed-loop system, which guarantees system stability, energy preservation, and disturbance rejection. Theoretical analysis and simulation results indicate that the proposed approach is robust, effective, and outperforms previously proposed methods for nonlinear systems.
column3: Robust PI Passivity-based Control of Nonlinear Systems: Application to  Port-Hamiltonian Systems and Temperature Regulation

column1: This paper presents a study on event-triggered observers and observer-based controllers for a certain class of nonlinear systems. The proposed approach utilizes a method that reduces the frequency of observer and controller updates, leading to reduced computational costs and improved stability guarantees. The paper establishes the theoretical framework for the event-triggered observer and controller design, and provides simulation results that demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. Overall, this paper presents a promising approach for efficient and robust control of nonlinear systems, particularly in applications where computational resources are limited.
column3: Event-Triggered Observers and Observer-Based Controllers for a Class of  Nonlinear Systems

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach for quickest change detection in adaptive censoring sensor networks. The proposed method utilizes an online learning algorithm to efficiently detect changes in the sensor data, and adapts to the dynamic nature of the network through censoring of observations. The effectiveness of the proposed method is evaluated through simulations, which demonstrate its superior performance in detecting changes in a timely manner while minimizing false alarms. This approach has the potential to improve the reliability and efficiency of sensor networks in a variety of applications.
column3: Quickest Change Detection in Adaptive Censoring Sensor Networks

column1: This paper focuses on the estimation of synchronous generator parameters using Phasor Measurement Unit (PMU) data. The estimation method employs the Least Squares Estimation (LSE) technique which is based on least square error minimization. The proposed method includes the derivation of the state-space model of a synchronous generator and the development of an algorithm for the estimation of the generator parameters. The effectiveness of the proposed method is evaluated through simulation studies and the results show that the proposed method outperforms conventional methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. The proposed method provides a powerful tool for accurate and reliable estimation of synchronous generator parameters in real-time power system applications.
column3: Least Squares Estimation-Based Synchronous Generator Parameter  Estimation Using PMU Data

column1: This paper presents a formal traffic characterization of LTI event-triggered control systems. Specifically, it proposes a framework that enables the estimation and analysis of traffic loads generated by event-triggered control systems. The framework also provides insights into the impact of system parameters on traffic behaviors, such as network congestion and packet loss. Through simulations and experiments, the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed framework are demonstrated. This research contributes to the development of event-triggered control systems by providing a formal and systematic approach to traffic analysis and management.
column3: A Formal Traffic Characterization of LTI Event-triggered Control Systems

column1: This paper addresses the challenging problems of leader selection and weight adjustment in multi-agent systems. The selection of suitable leaders and the appropriate distribution of weight values are crucial for achieving efficient and effective coordination among agents. This paper proposes a novel approach that integrates leader selection and weight adjustment strategies to improve the performance of multi-agent systems. The proposed approach is based on a distributed algorithm that utilizes local information and feedback from neighboring agents to make informed decisions about leader selection and weight adjustments. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed approach in various multi-agent scenarios. The findings presented in this paper have significant implications for the design and implementation of multi-agent coordination strategies.
column3: Leader selection and weight adjustment problems for multi-agent systems

column1: This paper presents a decentralized scalable approach to voltage control of DC islanded microgrids. The proposed approach utilizes both local and global control strategies to maintain voltage stability in the system. The decentralized control scheme allows for individual control of each distributed energy resource, while the global control maintains the overall voltage profile of the microgrid. The scalability of the approach allows for easy integration of additional resources to the microgrid without the need for extensive system reconfiguration. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in maintaining voltage stability and regulating the voltage profile of the microgrid under various load and generation conditions.
column3: A decentralized scalable approach to voltage control of DC islanded  microgrids

column1: This paper presents a novel approach to achieve consensus over random networks through sampled-data techniques. The proposed method addresses the challenge of limited bandwidth and computational resources by introducing a time-varying sampling scheme that ensures desired convergence rates while minimizing the communication load. The theoretical analysis demonstrates the stability and convergence of the system under various network topologies and sampling rates. The effectiveness of the proposed method is further verified through simulation results, which show significant improvements in convergence performance compared to existing approaches. This paper provides a valuable contribution to the field of distributed control and consensus algorithms over random networks.
column3: Sampled-Data Consensus over Random Networks

column1: This paper presents a two-part study on the application of AC optimal power flow (OPF) in radial distribution networks. In Part I, the mathematical formulation of the AC OPF problem is discussed along with the constraints and objective functions that need to be considered. The methodology for solving the problem is also presented, which involves the use of a nonlinear solver to obtain the optimal solution. In Part II, the effectiveness of the AC OPF approach is evaluated through simulation studies on a variety of test systems. The simulation results demonstrate that AC OPF can significantly improve the system performance in terms of voltage stability, power losses, and voltage regulation. The study also highlights the sensitivity of the optimal solution to different operational and technical constraints, and provides insights into the practical implementation of AC OPF in real-world distribution systems. Overall, the two-part study contributes to the literature on AC OPF and its potential benefits for enhancing the reliability and efficiency of radial distribution networks.
column3: AC OPF in Radial Distribution Networks - Parts I,II

column1: This paper proposes a novel event-triggered control approach for efficient control over unreliable networks that are subject to jamming attacks. The proposed method utilizes a dynamic event-triggering mechanism to reduce communication overhead and improve the performance of control systems. The method also considers the impact of jamming attacks on the system's performance, and provides a robust control strategy that is capable of maintaining stability and performance even in the presence of such attacks. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through extensive simulations, showing superior performance compared to existing control methods in the presence of jamming attacks. The results highlight the potential of event-triggered control for achieving efficient and secure control over unreliable networks.
column3: Event-Triggered Control over Unreliable Networks Subject to Jamming  Attacks

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach for the output feedback control of inhomogeneous parabolic partial differential equations (PDEs) with point actuation and point measurement using sum-of-squares (SOS) and semi-separable kernels. The proposed methodology combines the advantages of SOS and semi-separable kernels to design a controller that guarantees the stability and robustness of the system with an arbitrary degree of accuracy. The performance of the controller is analyzed through numerical simulations and compared with other conventional control design methods. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach provides an efficient and effective solution for controlling inhomogeneous parabolic PDEs with point actuation and measurement.
column3: Output Feedback Control of Inhomogeneous Parabolic PDEs with Point  Actuation and Point Measurement using SOS and Semi-Separable Kernels

column1: This paper aims to examine the concept of Minimal Reachability Problems (MRPs). MRPs constitute a class of computational problems that entail identifying the smallest set of nodes in a directed graph that must be traversed to reach a given target node through a directed path. This paper discusses the formulation of MRPs, their relevance in different fields of computer science and algorithmic techniques that have been proposed for solving them. Furthermore, we present recent developments in MRPs with emphasis on approximation algorithms and other optimization techniques. Finally, computational experiments with different kinds of graphs are presented to evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithms for MRPs.
column3: Minimal Reachability Problems

column1: This paper proposes a novel approach for analyzing the robustness of connectivity in multi-agent systems. The method is based on mathematical modeling and simulation of different scenarios that can cause connectivity failures in such systems. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, we apply it to a variety of multi-agent systems, including robotic networks, autonomous vehicles, and wireless sensor networks. Results show that our method can accurately predict connectivity failures and help designers develop more robust systems. This paper contributes to the fields of robotics, control theory, and network engineering, by providing a more comprehensive framework for connectivity analysis in multi-agent systems.
column3: Robust Connectivity Analysis for Multi-Agent Systems

column1: This paper proposes a data-driven power control approach for state estimation using Bayesian inference. In the proposed approach, data from the power system is used to estimate the system state in a Bayesian framework. The paper presents the model for the data-driven power control approach and describes the Bayesian inference process. The proposed approach is evaluated using a simulation study on a test system, and the results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach for power system state estimation. The paper contributes towards the development of accurate and reliable power control techniques for modern power systems.
column3: Data-Driven Power Control for State Estimation: A Bayesian Inference  Approach

column1: This paper aims to study optimal control in Markov decision processes (MDPs) through the lens of distributed optimization. We propose a novel method for solving MDPs that involves breaking down the problem into smaller, more manageable sub-problems and optimizing each sub-problem in a distributed manner. The resulting solution is then merged together to form an optimal policy for the original MDP. We also demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through numerical simulations and compare it against other state-of-the-art methods. Our results show that our method is both efficient and effective in solving MDPs, especially in scenarios where computation and communication resources are limited.
column3: Optimal control in Markov decision processes via distributed  optimization

column1: This paper explores computational methods for solving stochastic control problems in the presence of Metric Interval Temporal Logic (MITL) specifications. In particular, we focus on the use of MITL specifications to specify desired behaviors of a system, where constraints may be temporal, involve uncertainty, or both. Our approach involves the development of algorithms for synthesizing controllers that can satisfy MITL specifications in a stochastic environment, as well as the use of simulation-based methods for verifying the correctness of these controllers. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our methods through a case study in which we apply our approach to a simulated robotic system. Overall, this paper presents a novel framework for stochastic control with MITL specifications, highlighting the importance of computational techniques in advancing control theory.
column3: Computational methods for stochastic control with metric interval  temporal logic specifications

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for detecting the topology of a distribution system using consumer load and line flow measurements. Traditional methods rely on network model assumptions and may require significant data collection efforts. In contrast, our approach takes advantage of readily available data and only requires a limited set of measurements. By analyzing the power consumption patterns of consumers and the corresponding line flows, we develop algorithms that can accurately detect the network topology without relying on explicit network models. We also provide simulation results to demonstrate the efficacy of our approach, and discuss potential applications in smart grid and distribution system management.
column3: Distribution System Topology Detection Using Consumer Load and Line Flow  Measurements

column1: This paper presents a method for achieving safe platooning of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) through reachability analysis. The method involves calculating the reachable sets of each UAV in the platoon and using these sets to determine safe and feasible trajectories. The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of the approach through simulation and discusses potential extensions and applications of the method. Overall, this work presents a promising avenue for achieving safe and efficient UAV platooning in a variety of contexts.
column3: Safe Platooning of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles via Reachability

column1: This paper proposes a Global Tracking Passivity-based PI control strategy for bilinear systems, which can effectively improve the closed-loop stability and the tracking performance of these systems. The proposed control strategy is then applied to two widely used power electronic converters, the Boost Converter and the Modular Multilevel Converter, and their performances are experimentally validated. The results show that the proposed control strategy provides superior tracking performance compared to other control strategies, and therefore has potential application prospects in power electronic systems.
column3: Global Tracking Passivity--based PI Control of Bilinear Systems and its  Application to the Boost and Modular Multilevel Converters

column1: This paper presents an analytical formulation to accurately estimate the natural oscillation frequency of power systems. The proposed methodology employs mathematical models that account for the dynamic response of the system to various perturbations. The developed approach is validated using simulations on a realistic benchmark system, and the results demonstrate the effectiveness and accuracy of the proposed technique. The proposed analytical formulation serves as a useful tool for power system operators to maintain system stability and enhance the performance of the power network.
column3: An Analytical Formulation of Power System Oscillation Frequency

column1: This paper provides a survey of the latest advances in manoeuvring target tracking methods, including various tracking algorithms, system designs, and performance evaluations. With the increasing demand for more advanced and precise tracking technology, this survey aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the most promising tracking methods currently available. The survey covers both deterministic and stochastic tracking methods, as well as the latest developments in sensor fusion techniques. Additionally, the paper provides an analysis of the strengths and limitations of each method, giving readers a complete understanding of the current state-of-the-art in manoeuvring target tracking. This survey is an essential resource for researchers and practitioners alike who are interested in the latest advances in target tracking technology.
column3: A Survey of Manoeuvring Target Tracking Methods

column1: The paper Robust State Feedback Control Design with Probabilistic System Parameters presents a methodology for designing robust state feedback controllers in systems where the system parameters are uncertain and vary probabilistically. The proposed approach considers the probabilistic nature of uncertainties and incorporates them into the control design process to ensure effective control in real-world applications. The methodology is based on a combination of probabilistic and robust control theories and is illustrated through simulation studies on benchmark systems. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in improving the robustness of state feedback control systems while accounting for the uncertainties in the system parameters.
column3: Robust State Feedback Control Design with Probabilistic System  Parameters

column1: This paper proposes a novel framework for designing linear parameter varying (LPV) control systems using polynomial chaos theory. The LPV model is represented as a linear combination of basis functions and the control law is formulated as a polynomial in the parameters of the LPV model. The proposed framework leverages polynomial chaos expansions to obtain probability distributions of the LPV model parameters, enabling the design of robust control laws that account for uncertainty in the model parameters. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in designing LPV control systems that exhibit better performance and robustness compared to traditional LPV design approaches.
column3: A Polynomial Chaos Framework for Designing Linear Parameter Varying  Control Systems

column1: This paper proposes a new method for designing vibration control systems for nonlinear systems using the frequency response function. The method is based on a nonlinear system identification technique and employs a recursive least squares algorithm to estimate the system's frequency response function. The proposed approach involves the design of a linear controller that is optimized to achieve a desired closed-loop frequency response. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through numerical simulations of a nonlinear system with various degrees of complexity. The results show that the designed control system is capable of significantly reducing the vibrations of the system in response to external disturbances. This paper represents a valuable contribution to the field of vibration control and has important implications for a wide range of engineering applications.
column3: Vibration Control Design for Nonlinear Systems using Frequency Response  Function

column1: This paper proposes a method for detecting distribution system outages using consumer load and line flow measurements. The proposed approach harnesses the power of real-time measurements to accurately identify the location and extent of an outage in the distribution system. The paper presents a detailed analysis of the detection process, including the mathematical formulation and algorithmic implementation. The efficacy of the proposed method is validated through a series of simulations and case studies, which demonstrate its ability to detect outages accurately and quickly, thereby improving the reliability and resilience of the distribution system. Overall, this paper offers a valuable contribution to the field of distribution system monitoring and control.
column3: Distribution System Outage Detection using Consumer Load and Line Flow  Measurements

column1: This paper explores the concept of resilience, particularly in computational systems and environments. Resilience has become increasingly important due to the growing importance of systems that are both complex and critical. The paper discusses different models for understanding resilience, and considers how they can be applied to computational systems. It also explores the different behaviors that can be associated with resilience, including adaptability, redundancy, and robustness. Finally, the paper examines how resilience can be incorporated into the design of computational systems and environments, and the challenges that must be faced in order to do so.
column3: On Resilient Behaviors in Computational Systems and Environments

column1: This paper presents a bearing-based distributed control and estimation approach for multi-agent systems that allows agents to coordinate their movements and estimates using only relative bearing information. The proposed method leverages the graph Laplacian and consensus theory to develop a control law that ensures the agents reach a consensus while maintaining a desired formation. In addition, the estimation problem is addressed using the Extended Kalman Filter, allowing the agents to estimate the relative state information of their neighbors. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through simulation results under different scenarios. The presented approach shows promise for cooperative control applications in multi-robot systems.
column3: Bearing-Based Distributed Control and Estimation of Multi-Agent Systems

column1: This paper presents a novel approach for designing a Generalized Integral Sliding Mode (GISM) manifold using a Sum of Squares (SOS) optimization method. The proposed method is based on the use of Lyapunov stability theory and SOS polynomials to design a robust control law that guarantees the convergence of the system trajectory to the GISM manifold. The paper provides a detailed analysis of the proposed control design methodology and validates the effectiveness of the approach through simulation experiments. The results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method in comparison with the existing techniques in terms of the robustness and performance of the controlled system.
column3: Generalized Integral Siding Mode Manifold Design: A Sum of Squares  Approach

column1: This paper proposes a novel privacy-preserving multi-horizon utility-community decision making paradigm based on dual decomposition. The paradigm allows multiple stakeholders to collaborate and decide on a course of action while preserving their individual privacy. The proposed approach is based on a decomposition of the decision problem into sub-problems, where each stakeholder can solve their sub-problem without exposing their private information. The method guarantees decision optimality while ensuring that individual preferences and privacy are protected. The paper provides a theoretical analysis of the proposed paradigm and illustrates its application in a real-world scenario. Results show that the proposed method can effectively balance the trade-off between decision optimality and privacy preservation in multi-stakeholder decision-making problems.
column3: Dual Decomposition-Based Privacy-Preserving Multi-Horizon  Utility-Community Decision Making Paradigms

column1: This paper proposes a cooperative look-ahead control strategy to enhance fuel-efficiency and safety in heavy-duty vehicle platooning. The approach integrates predictive models of vehicle dynamics and traffic conditions to optimize the truck following distance and speed. The cooperative control considers the feedback from multiple trucks in the platoon regarding their current state, allowing for a flexible and adaptive formation. We present a simulation-based evaluation of the proposed strategy, showcasing its ability to achieve up to 15% fuel savings while maintaining a safe and stable platoon formation, even under various traffic scenarios. Our results indicate that the cooperative look-ahead control can offer a promising solution for improving the fuel-efficiency and safety of heavy-duty truck fleets.
column3: Cooperative look-ahead control for fuel-efficient and safe heavy-duty  vehicle platooning

column1: The implementation of toll lanes and dynamic pricing control has become increasingly important in managing traffic flow in large cities. This paper presents a modeling framework for toll lanes and dynamic pricing control, using a combination of mathematical and simulation-based approaches. The model accounts for the effects of pricing on travel behavior and congestion, and also considers factors such as toll revenue and environmental impacts. The results of the study indicate that implementing toll lanes and dynamic pricing control can significantly improve traffic flow efficiency, while generating additional revenue for transportation agencies. The proposed modeling framework can provide transportation planners with valuable insights into the potential benefits and challenges of implementing these strategies.
column3: Modeling Toll Lanes and Dynamic Pricing Control

column1: This paper presents a unified residential energy cost optimization model for smart grid systems, which aims to optimize the energy cost for residential consumers in a connected and responsive energy network.
